Epiphytic cacti native to tropical forests. Repot every 2-3 years in well-draining mix. Different care from desert cacti.

description: Also known as: Moon cactus. Small, round cacti with chin-like notches above each areole; Moon cactus is a colorful grafted form.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid intense direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Moon cactus is grafted—keep colorful top from burning. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact, round cacti with spiral tubercles and a crown of small flowers in spring.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect or direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Flowers form a ring around the crown in spring. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Round, woolly cactus covered in white hairs, produces pink flowers.
commonExamples: Mammillaria hahniana (Old lady cactus), M. bocasana (Powder puff cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Covered in white hairs giving woolly appearance. Produces pink flowers in spring. Repot every 3-5 years. Compact, round growth habit.

description: Flat-padded cactus with glochids (tiny barbed spines) instead of large spines; handle with care.
commonExamples: Opuntia microdasys (Bunny ears, Polka dot cactus)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Handle with extreme care—glochids detach easily and are very irritating. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Round, ribbed cacti that produce yellow or golden flowers from the crown.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect or direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer. Golden flowers bloom spring through summer. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Flat-padded cacti in the Opuntia genus, can produce edible fruit, very low-maintenance.
commonExamples: Opuntia ficus-indica (Indian fig opuntia), O. microdasys (Bunny ears), O. humifusa (Eastern prickly pear)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Full sun to bright indirect light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Flat, pad-like stems. Can produce edible fruit. Repot every 3-5 years. Handle with extreme care - tiny glochids are very irritating.

description: Trailing cactus with long, thin stems covered in spines, produces bright pink or red flowers.
commonExamples: Aporocactus flagelliformis (Rat tail cactus), Disocactus flagelliformis
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks in summer, less in winter). More water-tolerant than some cacti. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer at half strength. Trailing growth habit - perfect for hanging baskets. Produces bright pink or red flowers. Repot every 2-3 years. Long, thin trailing stems.

description: Genus-level entry: epiphytic jungle cacti with branching, often pendulous stems; spineless and ideal for hanging baskets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic—well-draining mix. Trailing habit suits hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Epiphytic Rhipsalis with slender, branching stems that may bear small white berries.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Spineless, trailing habit. Produces small white berries. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Small, round cactus with star-shaped pattern, very slow-growing and rare.
commonExamples: Astrophytum asterias (Star cactus, Sand dollar cactus, Sea urchin cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, very little in winter). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize sparingly (2-3 times per year) with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Very slow-growing. Star-shaped pattern on top. Produces yellow flowers. Repot every 3-5 years. Rare and protected in wild.

description: Also known as: Crab cactus. Forest cactus that blooms in late fall, similar to Christmas cactus but with pointed leaf segments.
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in fall (September-October) to encourage blooms. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pointed leaf segments distinguish from Christmas cactus. Blooms in late fall (Thanksgiving time). Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Compact flowering plants in the Gesneriaceae family with fuzzy leaves and colorful blooms, avoid getting water on leaves. Includes various cultivars with different flower colors, single, double, or ruffled flowers.
commonExamples: Saintpaulia ionantha (African violet), various cultivars with different flower colors, single, double, or ruffled flowers
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist. Always water from bottom or avoid wetting leaves - water on leaves causes permanent spots. Use room temperature water. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with African violet fertilizer to encourage continuous blooms. Repot annually in spring. Remove spent flowers. Crown rot is common - avoid overwatering.

description: Cane begonias with wing-shaped spotted leaves and pendent flower clusters in red, pink, or white.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun is fine. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Prune leggy stems to encourage bushiness. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Cane begonia with silver-spotted leaves, red undersides, and white flower clusters.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Leaf spots fade in low light. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Cultivar of polka dot begonia with larger, more prominent silver spots on dark green leaves and red undersides; produces white flower clusters.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Leaf spots fade in low light. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Silver vase plant. Bromeliads with pink flower spikes and silver-banded leaves.
commonExamples: Aechmea fasciata (Silver vase plant, Urn plant), A. 'Blue Rain'
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation and mosquito breeding. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. Flower spike lasts months. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent plant dies but pups can be separated and repotted.

description: Colorful bromeliads with bright, long-lasting flower spikes.
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. Bright, long-lasting flower spikes. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent dies but pups can be separated and repotted.

description: Tropical plants in the Bromeliaceae family with rosette growth and central cups (tanks) that hold water.
commonExamples: Guzmania (Flaming sword), Tillandsia (some species), Aechmea (Urn plant), Neoregelia (Blushing bromeliad)
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation and mosquito breeding. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent dies but pups can be separated. Most bloom once then produce pups.

description: Shade-tolerant flowering plant with strap-like leaves and striking orange or yellow flower clusters.
commonExamples: Clivia miniata (Kaffir lily, Bush lily), C. nobilis
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Needs a cool, dry rest period (6-8 weeks in fall) with minimal watering to trigger blooming. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Keep slightly pot-bound to encourage flowering. Fertilize monthly spring through summer. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Arabian coffee. Glossy-leaved shrub that can produce white flowers and red coffee cherries indoors.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Berries need several years to ripen. Acidic soil preferred. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing gesneriad with tubular flowers resembling goldfish; ideal for hanging baskets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact winter rest encourages blooming. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Thorny succulent shrub with colorful bracts that bloom year-round in bright light.
commonExamples: Euphorbia milii (Crown of thorns, Christ plant)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Milky sap is irritating—handle with care. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Tuberous flowering plants in the Primulaceae family with heart-shaped leaves and upswept flowers.
commonExamples: Cyclamen persicum (Florist's cyclamen), C. hederifolium (Hardy cyclamen), various colors
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water from bottom to avoid wetting leaves and crown. Cool temperatures (60-65°F) extend bloom time. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (50%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during flowering with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Goes dormant after flowering - reduce watering and allow foliage to die back. Repot when dormant. Upswept, colorful flowers.

description: Also known as: Cape jasmine. Fragrant flowering shrubs in the Rubiaceae family with glossy leaves and white blooms, require high humidity.
commonExamples: Gardenia jasminoides (Cape jasmine, Common gardenia), G. 'August Beauty', G. 'Veitchii'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (water when top inch is dry). Acidic soil essential (pH 5.0-6.5). Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks spring through fall with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Very fragrant white flowers. Prune after flowering. Can be finicky - requires consistent care. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Tuberous flowering plants in the Gesneriaceae family with velvety leaves and large, bell-shaped flowers.
commonExamples: Sinningia speciosa (Gloxinia, Florist's gloxinia), various colors and patterns
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water from bottom to avoid wetting leaves. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during flowering with high-phosphorus fertilizer. Goes dormant after flowering - reduce watering and allow foliage to die back. Repot when dormant. Large, bell-shaped velvety flowers. Velvety leaves.

description: Trailing gesneriad with waxy, fish-shaped flowers in orange or red; blooms from leaf axils.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Cooler, drier winter promotes spring blooms. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Chinese hibiscus. Showy shrub with large, colorful trumpet flowers that last one day but bloom repeatedly.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize weekly spring through fall with bloom fertilizer. Bud drop from stress or pests. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Wax plant. Classic wax plant with thick, waxy leaves and fragrant star-shaped flowers.
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa (Wax plant, Porcelain flower), H. carnosa 'Krimson Princess', H. carnosa 'Compacta'
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than many houseplants. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun encourages flowering. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't remove spent flower stems (peduncles) - they rebloom. Repot every 2-3 years. Fragrant star-shaped flowers. Can trail or climb.

description: Heart-shaped hoya often sold as single leaves, slow-growing but charming.
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Very slow-growing - single leaves may never grow into full plant. If you have a stem cutting (not just leaf), it will grow. Repot every 2-3 years. Charming heart-shaped leaves.

description: Epiphytic vines in the Apocynaceae family with waxy leaves and fragrant star-shaped flowers, also called wax plants.
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa (Wax plant, Porcelain flower), H. pubicalyx, H. kerrii (Sweetheart hoya, Valentine hoya)
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than many houseplants. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun encourages flowering. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't remove spent flower stems - they rebloom. Repot every 2-3 years. Fragrant star-shaped flowers. Can trail or climb.

description: Also known as: Pink jasmine. Fragrant flowering vines in the Oleaceae family, popular for their sweet-smelling blooms.
commonExamples: Jasminum polyanthum (Pink jasmine), J. sambac (Arabian jasmine), J. officinale (Common jasmine)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (water when top inch is dry). Bright indirect to direct light preferred - more light encourages flowering. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Provide support for climbing. Prune after flowering. Very fragrant flowers. Can be grown as houseplant or outdoor in warm climates. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Flowering succulents in the Crassulaceae family with vibrant long-lasting blooms and fleshy leaves.
commonExamples: Kalanchoe blossfeldiana (Flaming Katy, Florist kalanchoe), K. tomentosa (Panda plant, Chocolate soldier), Bryophyllum daigremontianum (Mother of thousands, syn. K. daigremontiana)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves which can cause rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. To rebloom, provide 12-14 hours of darkness daily for 6 weeks. Remove spent flowers. Repot every 1-2 years. Vibrant long-lasting blooms.

description: Also known as: Widow's thrill. Succulent with clusters of small flowers in red, pink, orange, or yellow; long-lasting bloom.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer. Short-day plant—reduce light in fall to rebloom. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Lipstick vine. Trailing gesneriad with tubular red flowers emerging from dark calyxes like lipstick.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun encourages blooms. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Trailing habit suits hanging baskets. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Vining plant with trumpet flowers in pink, red, or white; blooms from spring through fall.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize weekly spring through fall with bloom fertilizer. Provide trellis or support for climbing. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Aroids with white spathes and dark green foliage, excellent air purifiers, droop dramatically when thirsty as a watering indicator. Includes various cultivars ranging from compact to large.
commonExamples: Spathiphyllum wallisii (Peace lily), S. wallisii 'Domino', S. 'Sensation', S. floribundum, S. 'Mauna Loa'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy, water when leaves droop slightly. Fertilize every 6-8 weeks during growing season. Remove spent flowers to encourage new blooms. Repot when roots fill container, typically every 1-2 years. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth irritation.

description: Also known as: Moth orchid. Moth orchids, most common and beginner-friendly orchid genus in the Orchidaceae family with long-lasting blooms. Available in various colors.
commonExamples: Phalaenopsis (Moth orchid, Phal), various hybrid cultivars in many colors
careTips: Soak roots weekly for 15-20 minutes, then allow to dry between waterings. Never let sit in water. Avoid getting water in crown (center) which causes fatal crown rot. Use well-draining orchid bark mix, never regular potting soil. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize weekly spring through fall with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 1-2 years when bark breaks down. Blooms last 2-3 months. Most beginner-friendly orchid.

description: Foliage begonias prized for colorful, patterned leaves in shades of silver, pink, red, and green. Includes stunning colorful and patterned varieties.
commonExamples: Begonia rex-cultorum, B. maculata (Polka dot begonia), B. 'Escargot', B. 'Iron Cross', various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry completely. High humidity (60-70%) preferred - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant leaf colors; direct sun fades colors. Avoid wetting leaves which causes spots. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Water from bottom when possible. Repot every 1-2 years. Prone to powdery mildew - ensure good air circulation.

description: Tuberous gesneriad with velvety, bell-shaped flowers in many colors; florist gloxinia.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry; avoid wetting leaves. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%). Fertilize monthly during bloom. Goes dormant after flowering—reduce water until new growth. Bottom watering preferred. Repot when tuber outgrows pot.

description: Gesneriad with strappy leaves and trumpet flowers in blue, purple, pink, or white.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Long blooming season. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Flowering begonias grown from tubers, often with large showy blooms in various colors.
commonExamples: Begonia × tuberhybrida (Tuberous begonia), various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during active growth (spring through fall). Reduce watering significantly during dormancy period (winter) when leaves die back. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct hot sun. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during active growth with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage blooms. Store tubers dry in winter. Repot tubers in spring. Large showy blooms in various colors.

description: Tropical plant with bold white-veined leaves and showy yellow bract flowers; requires consistent moisture and high humidity.
commonExamples: Aphelandra squarrosa (Zebra plant, Saffron spike zebra)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light essential. High humidity (60-70%) required—use pebble tray or humidifier. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prone to leaf drop if care is inconsistent. Non-toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Peacock plant, Cathedral windows. Prayer plant with oval leaves featuring peacock-like patterns, leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia makoyana (Peacock plant, Cathedral windows), Calathea makoyana
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Repot every 1-2 years. Peacock-like pattern on leaves.

description: Popular prayer plant with dark green leaves and purple undersides, requires high humidity, leaves fold up at night.
commonExamples: Goeppertia roseopicta 'Medallion' (Calathea medallion), G. roseopicta 'Dottie' (darker variety), G. roseopicta 'Rosy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water and low humidity.

description: Also known as: Round-leaved calathea. Large prayer plant with silver-striped round leaves, requires high humidity, leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty).
commonExamples: Goeppertia orbifolia (Calathea orbifolia, Round-leaved calathea), one of the larger calathea varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun fades silver stripes. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. One of the larger calathea varieties. Wipe large leaves monthly.

description: Prayer plant with wavy, patterned leaves resembling a rattlesnake's tail.
commonExamples: Goeppertia lancifolia (Calathea rattlesnake, syn. Calathea lancifolia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wavy, patterned leaves resembling rattlesnake's tail. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water and low humidity.

description: Prayer plant with variegated leaves in white, green, and lavender; leaves fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) essential—variegation reverts in low humidity. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Prayer plant with bold white stripes on dark green leaves; leaves fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Prayer plant with velvety stripes alternating dark and light green; leaves fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium to high humidity (50-60%). Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold at night. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Fishbone prayer plant. Prayer plants in the Marantaceae family with patterned leaves that fold up at night, more tolerant than some prayer plants.
commonExamples: Ctenanthe burle-marxii (Fishbone prayer plant), C. oppenheimiana (Giant bamburanta), C. 'Golden Mosaic'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) preferred - more tolerant than some prayer plants. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Patterned leaves. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Prayer plant with fishbone-patterned leaves in silver and green; leaves fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium to high humidity (50-60%). Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. More tolerant than some prayer plants. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Prayer plant with silvery-green mosaic-patterned leaves; leaves fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium to high humidity (50-60%). Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Classic prayer plant with red-veined, herringbone-patterned leaves that fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (60-70%) preferred—use humidifier or pebble tray. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Classic prayer plant with red-veined leaves that fold up at night.
commonExamples: Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant), M. leuconeura 'Erythroneura', M. leuconeura 'Kerchoveana'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) preferred - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Red-veined leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly.

description: Also known as: Mosaic plant. Colorful foliage plants in the Acanthaceae family with distinctive veining in various colors, will wilt dramatically when thirsty.
commonExamples: Fittonia albivenis, F. verschaffeltii (Nerve plant, Mosaic plant), F. 'Pink Angel', F. 'Red Anne'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (70%+) essential - use humidifier or terrarium. Will wilt dramatically when thirsty but recovers quickly when watered. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for terrariums. Distinctive veining in various colors.

description: Plants in Marantaceae family with leaves that fold up at night (nyctinasty), require high humidity.
commonExamples: Calathea (Goeppertia), Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant), Stromanthe sanguinea
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water, low humidity, and drafts.

description: Prayer plants in the Marantaceae family with colorful, patterned leaves that fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Colorful, patterned leaves. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Prayer plant with star-shaped variegation in cream and green; leaves fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) essential—use humidifier or pebble tray. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Prayer plant with tricolor leaves—pink, cream, and green—that fold up at night.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) essential—use humidifier or pebble tray. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pink undersides visible when leaves fold. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: String of nickels. Epiphytic succulents related to Hoya, with coin-shaped or heart-shaped leaves; trailing or climbing habit.
commonExamples: Dischidia nummularia (String of nickels), D. ruscifolia
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic—well-draining mix. Trailing habit suits hanging baskets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Classic trailing vine with lobed leaves, can be grown indoors or outdoors.
commonExamples: Hedera helix (English ivy, Common ivy), H. helix 'Glacier', H. helix 'Needlepoint'
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist. Cooler temperatures (60-70°F) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prone to spider mites - mist regularly and inspect leaves. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Can be grown indoors or outdoors. Toxic to pets.

description: Trailing vine with grape-like leaves, easy-care houseplant.
commonExamples: Cissus rhombifolia (Grape ivy, Oak leaf ivy), C. alata
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Easy-care houseplant. Grape-like leaves. Can trail or climb with support.

description: Vining Hoya with waxy, oval leaves and fragrant white flowers with red centers.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Allow soil to dry between waterings. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Hoya carnosa cultivar with twisted, curled leaves creating a rope-like appearance; Hindu rope.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Slow-growing. Waxy pink flowers when mature. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing Hoya with small, silver-mottled leaves; ideal for hanging baskets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing Hoya with long, narrow, fuzzy leaves; pendulous habit suits hanging baskets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fragrant white flowers. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact Hoya with silver-flecked leaves; hybrid of H. serpens × H. carnosa.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Slow-growing. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Hoya with large, round, splash-dotted leaves; vining or trailing habit.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pink flowers in clusters. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Variegated Hoya obovata with cream or silver splashes on round leaves.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred to maintain variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Fast-growing Hoya with silver-flecked leaves and fragrant dark pink or red flowers.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prolific bloomer. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing peperomia with tiny leaves patterned like turtle shells; delicate vine.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Susceptible to overwatering. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Lemon-lime philodendron. Variegated heart-leaf philodendron with green and yellow-chartreuse leaves, easy-care trailing plant.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing trailing plant. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Green and yellow-chartreuse variegation. Toxic to pets.

description: Trailing pilea with small, bright green leaves; forms a dense mat, ideal for terrariums or hanging baskets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Silver pothos. Trailing aroids often called satin pothos, with silvery-splotched leaves, easy-care houseplants.
commonExamples: Scindapsus pictus (Satin pothos, Silver pothos), S. pictus 'Argyraeus', S. pictus 'Exotica', S. treubii 'Moonlight'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light maintains silvery variegation; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Trailing growth habit. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Silvery-splotched leaves. Often called satin pothos but not a true pothos. Toxic to pets.

description: Satin pothos with large, silvery-splotched leaves; trailing aroid, not a true pothos.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light maintains silver variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Satin pothos with solid silver-green leaves; Moonlight cultivar, more uniform than Exotica.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Spiderwort. Fast-growing trailing plants in the Commelinaceae family with colorful striped or solid leaves.
commonExamples: Tradescantia zebrina (Inch plant, Wandering Jew, Silver inch plant), T. fluminensis, T. pallida (Purple heart)
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist, allow to dry slightly between waterings. Very fast-growing - may need frequent pruning. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors; low light causes leggy growth. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for hanging baskets. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Toxic to pets.

description: Trailing plant with thick, striped leaves in pink, green, and cream; compact, upright-then-cascading habit.
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist. Bright indirect light maintains pink stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Trailing plant with vivid purple foliage and small pink flowers; can be grown indoors or outdoors.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect to direct light enhances purple color. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Wandering Jew. Fast-growing trailing plant with purple and silver striped leaves.
commonExamples: Tradescantia zebrina (Inch plant, Wandering Jew, Silver inch plant)
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist, allow to dry slightly between waterings. Very fast-growing. Bright indirect light maintains purple and silver stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for hanging baskets. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Toxic to pets.

description: Houseplants with trailing or climbing growth habits, popular for hanging baskets and shelves. Many are fast-growing and easy to propagate.
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum (Pothos), Hedera helix (English ivy), Tradescantia (Spiderwort), Hoya (Wax plant), Ceropegia woodii (String of hearts)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Most are forgiving of occasional missed waterings. Bright indirect to medium light preferred — most tolerate lower light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine for most species. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushier growth — cuttings root easily in water. Provide support (moss pole, trellis) for climbing species. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Fast-growing grasses in the Poaceae family, can be clumping or running types, popular for screening and containers.
commonExamples: Bambusa (Clumping bamboo), Phyllostachys (Running bamboo), Fargesia (Cold-hardy clumping bamboo), indoor varieties like Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Running types spread aggressively - contain with barriers or plant in containers. Clumping types are more manageable. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize monthly during growing season with high-nitrogen fertilizer. Prune to control height and remove old canes. Container-grown bamboo needs regular repotting. Research clumping vs running types before planting. Some species are invasive - check local regulations. Indoor lucky bamboo grows in water or soil.

description: Also known as: Crane flower. Large tropical plants in the Strelitziaceae family with distinctive bird-like flowers and banana-like leaves.
commonExamples: Strelitzia reginae (Bird of paradise, Crane flower), S. nicolai (Giant white bird of paradise, Wild banana)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist in growing season, reduce in winter. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - needs lots of light to flower. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Distinctive bird-like flowers. Can grow quite large - provide adequate space. Toxic to pets.

description: Miniature trees created through cultivation techniques - care varies by species, this is a general guide.
careTips: Water when soil surface is dry - check daily as small pots dry quickly. Avoid both over and under-watering. Adjust based on species needs - research your specific tree type. Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with bonsai fertilizer. Prune regularly to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years with bonsai soil mix. Requires patience and consistent care. Each species has specific requirements.

description: Also known as: Painted nettle. Colorful foliage plants in the Lamiaceae family with vibrant leaves in various patterns and colors, pinch flowers to maintain foliage.
commonExamples: Plectranthus scutellarioides (Coleus, Painted nettle), various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors; direct sun may fade colors. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch flower spikes immediately to encourage leaf growth - flowers signal end of plant's life. Pinch tips regularly to maintain bushy growth. Repot annually. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Annual in most climates.

description: Also known as: Garden croton. Colorful tropical foliage plants in the Euphorbiaceae family with vibrant leaves in red, orange, yellow, and green, sensitive to changes.
commonExamples: Codiaeum variegatum (Croton, Garden croton), C. variegatum 'Petra', C. variegatum 'Mammy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. High humidity (60%+) preferred - use humidifier. Bright indirect to direct light essential to maintain vibrant colors. Sensitive to changes - avoid moving once established. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. May drop leaves if stressed (drafts, temperature changes, low humidity). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Croton cultivar with twisted, spiral leaves in red, orange, yellow, and green.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. Bright indirect to direct light essential for vibrant colors. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Sensitive to drafts and changes. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Ancient palm-like plants in the Cycadaceae family, slow-growing with stiff fronds, many are endangered in the wild.
commonExamples: Cycas revoluta (Sago palm, King sago), Zamia (Coontie, Cardboard palm), Dioon (Dioon cycad), Macrozamia
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry slightly between waterings - avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with palm fertilizer. Very slow-growing - repot every 3-5 years. Remove dead fronds at base. Toxic to pets if ingested. Ancient plants that have existed for millions of years. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Bold tropical foliage plant with large, deeply lobed palmately compound leaves.
commonExamples: Fatsia japonica (Japanese aralia, Paper plant), F. japonica 'Spider Web'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light; tolerates lower light. High humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Can grow large; prune to control size. Toxic to pets.

description: Ficus with glossy oval leaves, popular for bonsai; can develop aerial roots.
commonExamples: Ficus microcarpa (Chinese banyan, Ginseng ficus, Banyan fig), F. microcarpa 'Green Island'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Often grown as bonsai. Avoid moving once established. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: FLF. Popular but finicky ficus with large violin-shaped leaves, requires consistent care and stable environment.
commonExamples: Ficus lyrata (Fiddle-leaf fig, FLF), F. lyrata 'Bambino' (compact variety), F. lyrata variegated (rare)
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Very sensitive to overwatering and location changes - may drop leaves. Avoid drafts and sudden temperature changes. Bright indirect light essential - rotate regularly for even growth. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular but finicky - requires consistent care and stable environment. Toxic to pets.

description: Bright golden conifer with lemony scent, popular as indoor or patio plant, requires good air circulation.
commonExamples: Cupressus macrocarpa 'Goldcrest' (Lemon cypress, Goldcrest cypress, Monterey cypress 'Goldcrest')
careTips: Keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Excellent drainage essential. Allow top inch to dry slightly between waterings. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Good air circulation essential - avoid stagnant air. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years. Bright golden color with lemony scent. Popular as indoor or patio plant.

description: Also known as: Chinese water bamboo. Dracaena species often grown in water or soil, popular for feng shui, not a true bamboo.
commonExamples: Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo, Chinese water bamboo, Ribbon plant), can be grown in water or soil
careTips: In water: Change water weekly, keep water level consistent. In soil: Water when top inch is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength (if in soil) or add to water monthly. Can be grown in water indefinitely or in soil. Popular for feng shui arrangements. Not a true bamboo. Toxic to pets. Repot every 2-3 years if in soil.

description: Tropical tree with palmate leaves, often sold with braided trunk; symbol of prosperity and good luck.
commonExamples: Pachira aquatica (Money tree, Guiana chestnut, Malabar chestnut)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot—very sensitive to soggy soil. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Often sold with braided trunk—don't untie. Repot every 2-3 years. Remove yellowing leaves.

description: Also known as: Star pine. Indoor conifer native to Norfolk Island, popular as holiday plant, not a true pine but resembles one, sensitive to dry air. Requires consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Araucaria heterophylla (Norfolk Island pine, Star pine)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid drying out completely. High humidity (50-60%) preferred - mist regularly in dry conditions or use humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Sensitive to dry air - brown needles indicate low humidity. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular as holiday plant. Not a true pine despite the name.

description: Plants in the Oxalidaceae family with clover-like leaves that fold at night, some species go dormant seasonally.
commonExamples: Oxalis triangularis (Purple shamrock, False shamrock), O. regnellii (Green shamrock, Lucky clover)
careTips: Keep soil moist during active growth. Reduce significantly or stop watering during dormancy when leaves die back - this is normal. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly during active growth with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Clover-like leaves fold at night. Some species go dormant seasonally - don't discard, it will regrow. Repot every 2-3 years. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: False shamrock. Clover-like plant with purple triangular leaves that fold at night; produces small pink or white flowers.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun enhances purple. Medium humidity (40-50%). Goes dormant periodically—reduce watering when leaves die back. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Compact tropical foliage plants in the Piperaceae family with thick, succulent-like leaves.
commonExamples: Peperomia obtusifolia (Baby rubber plant), P. caperata (Emerald ripple), P. argyreia (Watermelon peperomia)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants due to succulent-like leaves. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth habit. Repot every 2-3 years. Easy-care houseplants. Thick, succulent-like leaves store water.

description: Compact peperomia with deeply ridged, heart-shaped leaves in red, green, or silver.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Susceptible to overwatering. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Hope peperomia. Trailing peperomia with small, round succulent-like leaves, perfect for hanging baskets.
commonExamples: Peperomia 'Hope' (P. deppeana × P. quadrifolia, Hope peperomia), trailing variety with round leaves
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Perfect for hanging baskets. Trailing growth habit. Small, round succulent-like leaves. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Peperomia with thick, glossy oval leaves; upright or trailing, not a true rubber plant.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Tolerates low light. Non-toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Compact peperomia with dark green tops and red undersides, star-shaped growth, textured leaves.
commonExamples: Peperomia caperata 'Rosso' (Peperomia Rosso), P. caperata 'Emerald Ripple' (green variety), P. caperata 'Luna Red'
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants. Bright indirect light enhances red undersides. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Star-shaped growth habit. Textured leaves with dark green tops and red undersides. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Compact peperomia with silver-striped leaves resembling watermelon rind.
commonExamples: Peperomia argyreia (Watermelon peperomia, syn. P. sandersii)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light maintains silver stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Silver-striped leaves resembling watermelon rind. Compact growth habit. Repot every 2-3 years. Easy-care houseplant.

description: Compact tropical foliage plants in the Urticaceae family with round or textured leaves.
commonExamples: Pilea peperomioides (Chinese money plant, Pancake plant, UFO plant), P. cadierei (Aluminum plant), P. involucrata (Friendship plant)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Avoid overwatering. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth habit. Round or textured leaves. Repot every 1-2 years. Easy to propagate from offsets or cuttings.

description: Also known as: UFO plant. Popular Pilea with round, coin-like leaves on upright stems.
commonExamples: Pilea peperomioides (Chinese money plant, Pancake plant, UFO plant)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light preferred; rotate regularly for even growth. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Produces offsets (pups) that can be separated and repotted. Repot every 1-2 years. Round, coin-like leaves on upright stems. Popular and easy-care.

description: Compact pilea with quilted, bronze-veined leaves; easy to propagate and share—hence the name.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity (40-50%). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Also known as: Kusamaki. Conifer-like evergreen with narrow leaves, popular for bonsai and topiary.
commonExamples: Podocarpus macrophyllus (Buddhist pine, Kusamaki, Yew pine), P. henkelii
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Tolerates lower light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to maintain shape. Good for bonsai. Toxic to pets.

description: Colorful foliage plants in the Acanthaceae family with spotted leaves in pink, red, or white, pinch to maintain bushy growth.
commonExamples: Hypoestes phyllostachya (Polka dot plant, Freckle face), various color cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. High humidity (60%+) preferred - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips regularly to encourage branching and maintain bushy growth. Pinch flowers immediately to prolong plant life. Repot annually. Annual in most climates. Easy to propagate from cuttings.

description: Popular ficus with large, glossy dark green or burgundy leaves, can grow into a tree.
commonExamples: Ficus elastica (Rubber plant, Rubber tree), F. elastica 'Burgundy'
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Sensitive to location changes - may drop leaves when moved. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large glossy leaves monthly. Prune to control height. Repot every 2-3 years. Can grow into a tree. Toxic to pets.

description: Ficus elastica cultivar with dark burgundy, nearly black leaves; bold statement plant.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%). Wipe leaves to remove dust. Toxic to pets. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Tropical shrub with glossy, palmately compound leaves—leaflets radiate from a central point like umbrella ribs.
commonExamples: Schefflera actinophylla (Umbrella tree, Octopus tree), S. arboricola (Dwarf umbrella tree, Hawaiian elf)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control size and encourage bushiness. Wipe leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Can grow quite large. Toxic to pets.

description: Deciduous conifer with feathery foliage and distinctive "knees"; tolerates wet or swampy sites.
careTips: Keep soil moist; tolerates standing water. Full sun preferred. Adapts to wet or dry sites once established. Fertilize in spring when young. Prune in late winter. Develops woody "knees" in wet soil. Golden fall color. Long-lived.

description: Deciduous trees in the Betulaceae family with distinctive white or colored bark, prefer cool climates and moist soil.
commonExamples: Betula papyrifera (Paper birch), B. nigra (River birch), B. pendula (Silver birch, European white birch), B. alleghaniensis (Yellow birch)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist, especially during hot weather. Prefer cool climates and moist, well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during establishment. Prune in late summer to avoid bleeding sap. Mulch around base to keep roots cool and moist. Distinctive white or colored bark. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Ornamental cherry with clouds of pink or white spring blossoms; iconic in Japanese gardens.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during bloom. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize after flowering. Prune after bloom to avoid disease; minimal pruning preferred. Short-lived (15–25 years). Susceptible to borers and diseases.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Rutaceae family with fragrant flowers and edible fruits, require warm climates or indoor protection.
commonExamples: Citrus limon (Lemon), C. sinensis (Orange, Sweet orange), C. × aurantifolia (Lime), C. reticulata (Mandarin, Tangerine)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly in growing season). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus-specific fertilizer. Prune after fruiting to maintain shape. Protect from frost - bring indoors or cover if temperatures drop below 32°F. Fragrant flowers precede fruit. Require warm climates or indoor protection in winter. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Cone-bearing evergreen trees and shrubs, include pines, spruces, firs, and cedars, provide year-round structure.
commonExamples: Pinus (Pine, Eastern white pine, Scots pine), Picea (Spruce, Norway spruce, Blue spruce), Abies (Fir, Balsam fir), Cedrus (Cedar), Juniperus (Juniper)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation. Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun preferred for most species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many species are drought-tolerant once established. Provide year-round structure and privacy screening. Research specific species for exact requirements and mature size. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Small flowering tree with spring blossoms and persistent ornamental fruit; many disease-resistant cultivars.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter; thin for airflow. Choose disease-resistant cultivars (e.g. scab, fire blight). Fruit attracts birds. Edible fruit in some cultivars.

description: Summer-blooming tree with crepe-paper flowers; smooth mottled bark, vivid fall color.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential for flowering. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter—avoid "crepe murder" topping. Mildew-resistant cultivars available. Heat and drought tolerant. Bark exfoliates attractively.

description: Trees that lose their leaves seasonally, provide shade in summer and allow light in winter.
commonExamples: Acer (Maple, Sugar maple, Red maple), Quercus (Oak, Red oak, White oak), Betula (Birch), Fraxinus (Ash), Ulmus (Elm)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly for first 2-3 years). Water well during establishment period. Mature trees are more drought tolerant but benefit from deep watering during dry spells. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring when dormant. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Provide shade in summer, allow light in winter. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Mesquite. Trees adapted to arid desert conditions, extremely drought tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Prosopis (Mesquite, Honey mesquite), Acacia (Acacia, Sweet acacia), Parkinsonia (Palo verde, Blue palo verde), Olneya (Ironwood)
careTips: Minimal watering once established (monthly or less). Deep but infrequent watering during establishment (first 1-2 years). Allow to dry completely between waterings. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil critical. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Prune in late winter. Extremely drought tolerant once established. Adapted to arid desert conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous trees and shrubs in the Cornaceae family with showy spring flowers and colorful fall foliage.
commonExamples: Cornus florida (Flowering dogwood), C. kousa (Kousa dogwood, Japanese dogwood), C. nuttallii (Pacific dogwood), C. mas (Cornelian cherry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering and fruit development. Prefer partial shade to full sun depending on climate. Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Showy spring flowers and colorful fall foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Trees that retain foliage year-round, provide year-round structure and privacy screening.
commonExamples: Pinus (Pine, Eastern white pine, Scots pine), Picea (Spruce, Norway spruce, Blue spruce), Abies (Fir, Balsam fir), Cedrus (Cedar)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation. Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Provide year-round structure and privacy screening. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous and evergreen trees grown for edible fruits, require proper pruning and often need cross-pollination.
commonExamples: Malus domestica (Apple), Prunus persica (Peach), Pyrus (Pear), Prunus avium (Cherry)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape and encourage fruiting. Many require cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties nearby. Thin fruit for larger, healthier fruits. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Also known as: Maidenhair tree. Ancient deciduous trees in the Ginkgoaceae family, living fossil, popular street tree in China, male and female trees.
commonExamples: Ginkgo biloba (Ginkgo, Maidenhair tree), male cultivars (no fruit), 'Autumn Gold', 'Princeton Sentry'
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment. Mature trees are drought tolerant. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in early spring during establishment. Prune in late winter. Ancient living fossil. Popular street tree in China. Plant male cultivars to avoid smelly fruit. Beautiful golden fall foliage. Very long-lived. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Hardy deciduous tree with fluted bark; excellent for hedging and topiary.
careTips: Keep soil moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Tolerates heavy pruning. Fertilize in spring when establishing. Prune in late summer; excellent for formal hedges. Fall color yellow to orange. Dense wood—"ironwood."

description: Graceful maple with delicate lobed leaves; red, green, or variegated; stunning fall color.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist; avoid drought stress. Partial shade preferred—full sun can scorch leaves. Well-draining, slightly acidic soil. Fertilize lightly in spring. Prune in winter when dormant. Protect from wind. Red cultivars need some sun for color.

description: Deciduous and evergreen trees in the Magnoliaceae family with large, fragrant flowers, many species are ancient flowering plants.
commonExamples: Magnolia grandiflora (Southern magnolia), M. × soulangeana (Saucer magnolia), M. stellata (Star magnolia), M. liliiflora (Lily magnolia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering. Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Large, fragrant flowers. Many species are ancient flowering plants. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Deciduous trees in the Sapindaceae family known for brilliant fall foliage, many species are popular landscape trees.
commonExamples: Acer saccharum (Sugar maple), A. rubrum (Red maple), A. palmatum (Japanese maple), A. platanoides (Norway maple), A. saccharinum (Silver maple)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment (first 2-3 years). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Mature trees are more drought tolerant. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during establishment. Prune in late winter when dormant. Mulch around base. Brilliant fall foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Majestic deciduous and evergreen trees in the Fagaceae family, provide shade and wildlife habitat, many species are long-lived.
commonExamples: Quercus rubra (Red oak), Q. alba (White oak), Q. virginiana (Live oak), Q. palustris (Pin oak), Q. robur (English oak)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment (first 2-3 years). Mature trees are drought tolerant but benefit from deep watering during extended dry periods. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during first 5 years. Prune in late winter when dormant. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Provide shade in summer. Many species live for centuries. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Evergreen conifers in the Pinaceae family with needle-like leaves and woody cones, many species are long-lived and widely planted for timber, shelter, and ornament.
commonExamples: Pinus sylvestris (Scots pine), P. strobus (Eastern white pine), P. ponderosa (Ponderosa pine), P. mugo (Mugo pine), P. nigra (Austrian pine)
careTips: Water deeply during establishment (first 2-3 years). Mature trees are drought tolerant once established. Full sun essential - at least 6 hours daily. Prefer acidic, well-drained soil. Fertilize young trees in early spring with acid-forming fertilizer. Prune candles in spring to control growth - avoid cutting into old wood. Mulch with pine needles to maintain soil acidity. Avoid planting in waterlogged soil. Evergreen - no seasonal leaf drop. Many species live for centuries. Toxic to pets.

description: Small tree with magenta flowers on bare branches in early spring; heart-shaped leaves.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering if needed. Nitrogen-fixing. Susceptible to canker—avoid wounding. Edible flowers. Fall color yellow.

description: Large shrub or small tree with pink flowers on branches before leaves; more heat-tolerant than Eastern redbud.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after flowering. Tolerates heat better than C. canadensis. Often multi-trunked. Fall color yellow.

description: Multi-trunk birch with distinctive peeling cinnamon-brown bark; tolerates wet soils.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; tolerates wet sites. Full sun to partial shade. Acidic soil preferred. Fertilize in spring when young. Prune in late summer to avoid sap bleed. Resistant to bronze birch borer. Heat-tolerant. Often grown multi-trunked.

description: Also known as: Juneberry. Small tree or large shrub with white spring flowers, edible berries, and brilliant fall color.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist when young. Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to various soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter. Edible berries attract birds. Excellent fall color. Native to North America. Multi-season interest.

description: Shrub or small tree with fluffy gray-pink "smoke" plumes and purple or green foliage.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best color and flowering. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter—cut hard for large leaves, light prune for plumes. Purple cultivars need full sun. Drought tolerant. Fall color orange to red. Mildly toxic to pets—sap may cause irritation; ingestion may cause GI upset.

description: Tall deciduous tree with star-shaped leaves and spiky seed balls; brilliant fall color.
careTips: Keep soil moist when young. Full sun preferred. Tolerates wet or dry soil. Fertilize in spring when establishing. Prune in late winter. Fall color red, orange, yellow. Seed balls can be messy—consider fruitless cultivars. Deep taproot.

description: Fast-growing tree with gracefully cascading branches; needs ample water and space.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist; thrives near water. Full sun. Plant away from pipes and foundations—aggressive roots. Prune in late winter. Fast growth. Short-lived (30–50 years). Weak wood—susceptible to storm damage. Avoid in small yards.

description: Also known as: Glossy abelia. Compact shrub with glossy leaves and tubular white-pink flowers; long bloom season.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune lightly after flowering. Semi-evergreen to evergreen. Attracts pollinators. Deer resistant.

description: Flowering shrubs in the Ericaceae family, part of the Rhododendron genus, prefer acidic soil and partial shade.
commonExamples: Rhododendron (Azalea), R. indicum (Southern Indian azalea), R. kiusianum (Kyushu azalea), evergreen and deciduous varieties, Kurume and Southern Indica hybrids
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Acidic soil essential (pH 4.5-6.0) - use acidifying fertilizer and mulch with pine needles or oak leaves. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering. Mulch to keep roots cool and retain moisture. Don't plant too deep - keep root ball slightly above soil level. Research evergreen vs deciduous varieties for your climate. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Thorny shrub with red, gold, or green foliage; small berries; invasive in many regions.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best color. Tolerates poor soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter—wear gloves for thorns. Deer resistant. Invasive in eastern North America—check local restrictions. Consider sterile cultivars. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Buxaceae family with dense foliage, popular for hedges and topiary, slow-growing and long-lived.
commonExamples: Buxus sempervirens (Common boxwood, English boxwood), B. microphylla (Littleleaf boxwood), B. sinica (Korean boxwood)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during establishment. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late spring or early summer to maintain shape. Mulch around base. Dense foliage perfect for hedges and topiary. Slow-growing and long-lived. Watch for boxwood blight and pests. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Shrub with corky winged branches; brilliant scarlet fall color; invasive in many areas.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun for best fall color. Adapts to most soils. Fertilize in spring. Prune in late winter. Invasive in eastern North America—avoid or use sterile cultivars. Berries toxic. Corky "wings" on stems distinctive.

description: Also known as: Summer lilac. Arching shrub with fragrant flower spikes; attracts butterflies; can be invasive.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune hard in late winter—flowers on new growth. Deadhead to prolong bloom. Invasive in some regions—choose sterile cultivars. Deer resistant.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Theaceae family with beautiful flowers, includes tea plant, popular in Chinese gardens.
commonExamples: Camellia japonica (Japanese camellia), C. sinensis (Tea plant), C. sasanqua (Sasanqua camellia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained, acidic soil essential. Partial shade preferred - avoid hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering. Beautiful flowers in winter/spring. Tea plant (C. sinensis) leaves are used for tea. Popular in Chinese gardens. Protect from harsh winds. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Bluebeard. Compact shrub with blue flower clusters in late summer; silvery-gray foliage.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Cut back hard in late winter—flowers on new growth. Drought tolerant. Attracts bees and butterflies. Deer resistant. Late-season bloomer.

description: Evergreen plants that tolerate cold winter temperatures, provide year-round structure and color in landscapes.
commonExamples: Buxus (Boxwood), Ilex (Holly, American holly, English holly), Taxus (Yew), Juniperus (Juniper), Thuja (Arborvitae)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during growing season. Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation (brown needles). Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Tolerate cold winter temperatures. Provide year-round structure and color. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Spreading shrub with herringbone branches, small leaves, and red berries; groundcover or upright.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun to partial shade. Well-draining soil. Fertilize in spring. Prune after berries drop. Fire blight susceptible. Berries attract birds. Some species invasive—check locally. Drought tolerant once established.

description: Woody shrubs that retain foliage year-round, provide structure and privacy in landscapes.
commonExamples: Buxus (Boxwood, American boxwood), Ligustrum (Privet), Ilex (Holly, American holly), Taxus (Yew), Camellia
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Keep consistently moist during establishment (first 1-2 years). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent desiccation. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with shrub fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape. Mulch around base. Provide structure and privacy year-round. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.
