description: Also known as: Broad-leaved endive. Broad-leaved chicory in the Asteraceae family; milder than curly endive, with flat, tender leaves for salads and cooking.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather; plant spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Blanch inner leaves for milder flavor. Harvest outer leaves or whole head. Less bitter than curly endive.

description: Also known as: Chinese broccoli, Kai-lan, Chinese kale. Chinese broccoli in the Brassicaceae family with thick stems and small flower heads, essential in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. alboglabra (Gai lan, Chinese broccoli, Kai-lan, Chinese kale)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest when flower buds are just forming. Both stems and leaves are edible. Prefer cool weather. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cold-hardy leafy green in the Brassicaceae family, flavor improves after frost, can overwinter in mild climates.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. acephala (Kale), curly kale, Lacinato (Dinosaur kale, Tuscan kale), Red Russian kale
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and keep leaves clean. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Flavor improves after frost. Can overwinter in mild climates. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Unique vegetables in the Brassicaceae family with swollen stem base, both bulb and leaves are edible, fast-growing.
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. gongylodes (Kohlrabi), green and purple varieties, 'Early White Vienna', 'Purple Vienna'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for tender bulbs. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when bulb is 2-3 inches in diameter for best flavor. Both bulb and leaves are edible. Fast-growing (45-60 days). Prefer cool weather. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Vegetables grown primarily for their edible leaves. Many are cool-season crops that bolt in heat. Quick to harvest and ideal for successive planting.
commonExamples: Lactuca sativa (Lettuce), Spinacia oleracea (Spinach), Brassica oleracea (Kale), Beta vulgaris (Swiss chard), Eruca vesicaria (Arugula)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist — water every 1-2 days in warm weather. Mulch to retain moisture and keep roots cool. Partial shade to full sun — most prefer cooler conditions and bolt (go to seed) in heat. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer for lush leaf growth. Harvest outer leaves first (cut-and-come-again) for continuous production. Succession plant every 2-3 weeks for ongoing harvest. Best grown in spring and fall — provide shade cloth in summer. Ready in 30-60 days depending on variety. Research specific vegetable for exact requirements.

description: Fast-growing leafy greens in the Asteraceae family, prefer cooler temperatures and can bolt (flower) in heat.
commonExamples: Lactuca sativa (Lettuce), butterhead, romaine, leaf lettuce, and crisphead varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed in hot weather). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting (premature flowering). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves which can cause disease. Partial shade in hot climates helps prevent bolting. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly or cut whole head. Fast-growing - ready in 45-60 days. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring and fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Heat-loving vining herb in the Basellaceae family; succulent leaves and stems. Thrives in summer when true spinach bolts.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun. Trellis or support for vining habit. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest young leaves and shoot tips. Heat-tolerant; grows when other greens struggle. Red-stemmed variety (B. alba 'Rubra') ornamental.

description: Japanese mustard green in the Brassicaceae family; feathery, serrated leaves with mild peppery flavor. Popular in salads and stir-fries.
commonExamples: Brassica juncea var. japonica (Japanese mustard, Mizuna)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather; plant spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Cut-and-come-again harvest. Fast-growing; ready in 40-50 days. Mild flavor; can bolt in heat.

description: Leafy green vegetables in the Brassicaceae family with peppery flavor, fast-growing and cold-hardy.
commonExamples: Brassica juncea (Mustard greens, Mustard spinach, Indian mustard), 'Southern Giant Curled', 'Red Giant', 'Tendergreen'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly. Fast-growing. Peppery flavor. Cold-hardy. Can bolt in heat. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Chinese cabbage, Wombok, Pe-tsai. Chinese cabbage in the Brassicaceae family with elongated, barrel-shaped heads, essential in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. pekinensis (Napa cabbage, Chinese cabbage, Wombok, Pe-tsai), 'Michihili', 'Blues', 'Rubicon'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head formation. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Harvest when heads are firm. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Can bolt in heat. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Succulent annual in the Portulacaceae family; fleshy leaves high in omega-3. Often foraged as a weed; cultivated for salads and cooking.
careTips: Drought tolerant; water when soil is dry. Full sun. Poor soil acceptable. Harvest stems and leaves when young. Self-sows; can become weedy. Tangy, slightly lemony flavor. Popular in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines.

description: Also known as: Chioggia, Treviso, Castelfranco. Chicory in the Asteraceae family with bitter, wine-red leaves; forms compact heads. Essential in Italian cuisine; bitterness mellows when grilled or roasted.
commonExamples: Cichorium intybus var. foliosum (Chioggia, Treviso, Castelfranco)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist. Full sun. Prefer cool weather; flavor improves after frost. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest when heads are firm. Cold temperatures deepen red color. Blanch some varieties for sweeter flavor.

description: Allium with mild edible green tops and white bases, used fresh in many cuisines.
commonExamples: Allium fistulosum (Welsh onion, Bunching onion), A. cepa 'Evergreen'
careTips: Keep soil moist. Full sun. Fast-growing. Harvest when tops are 6-8 inches. Can regrow from roots. Popular in Asian cooking. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cool-season leafy green in the Amaranthaceae family, bolts quickly in heat, best grown in spring and fall.
commonExamples: Spinacia oleracea (Spinach), smooth-leaf and savoy (crinkled) varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed). Consistent moisture prevents bolting (premature flowering) and ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Partial shade in warm climates. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly or cut whole plant. Bolts quickly in heat - best grown in spring and fall. Ready in 40-50 days. Watch for leaf miners. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Rainbow chard. Leafy green vegetable in the Amaranthaceae family with colorful stems, can be harvested continuously throughout season.
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris subsp. cicla (Swiss chard, Rainbow chard, Rhubarb chard), 'Bright Lights', 'Fordhook Giant', 'Ruby Red'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around plants. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Colorful stems in red, yellow, orange, and white. Can harvest continuously throughout season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Asian green in the Brassicaceae family; dark green spoon-shaped leaves in a flat rosette. Mild, mustard-like flavor; cold-hardy.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa var. rosularis (Rosette bok choy)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather; very cold-hardy. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest whole rosette or outer leaves. Fast-growing; ready in 45-50 days. Popular in Asian salads and stir-fries.

description: Edible leaves of the turnip root; nutritious, slightly peppery. Harvest before or alongside roots; flavor improves after light frost.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Full sun to partial shade. Fertile, well-drained soil. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest outer leaves when 4-6 inches; allows root to develop. Can grow for greens only or greens plus roots. Cold-hardy.

description: Also known as: Kangkong. Semi-aquatic vine in the Convolvulaceae family; hollow stems and tender leaves. Staples in Southeast Asian and Chinese cooking.
commonExamples: Ipomoea aquatica (Water spinach, Ong choy, Kangkong)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist or grow in shallow water. Full sun. Rich soil or aquatic setup. Fertilize regularly. Harvest shoot tips and young leaves. Invasive in some regions; check local regulations. Quick-growing; harvest frequently.

description: Small winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family with acorn-shaped dark green fruits and sweet orange flesh, good for roasting.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Compact vines suit smaller gardens. Harvest when rind is hard and dark green. Cure before storage. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Azuki bean, Red bean. Small red beans in the Fabaceae family, very popular in Chinese and Japanese cuisine, used in desserts.
commonExamples: Vigna angularis (Adzuki bean, Azuki bean, Red bean)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Fast-growing (90-120 days). Harvest when pods are dry and brown. Very popular in Chinese and Japanese cuisine. Used in desserts and sweet red bean paste. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Long, ribbed melon in the Cucurbitaceae family, eaten like cucumber when immature, mild and crisp, heat-tolerant.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily in hot weather). Water at base to avoid leaf diseases. Consistent moisture prevents bitter fruit. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Provide trellis for vining habit. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Harvest when 12-18 inches long for best flavor. Heat-tolerant. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Perennial thistle in the Asteraceae family, grown for edible flower buds before they bloom, Mediterranean origin.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during bud formation. Mulch to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in spring and after harvest. Perennial in zones 7–11; harvest flower buds when tight and before scales open. Mulch heavily in winter. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing legume vegetables in the Fabaceae family, pole beans need support while bush beans are self-supporting.
commonExamples: Phaseolus vulgaris (Green beans, Snap beans, String beans), pole and bush varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly - beans fix their own nitrogen. Pole beans need trellis or support; bush beans are self-supporting. Harvest regularly to encourage continued production. Fast-growing - ready in 50-60 days. Watch for bean beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Sweet pepper. Sweet peppers in the Solanaceae family with blocky, thick-walled fruits, most popular pepper variety.
commonExamples: Capsicum annuum (Bell pepper, Sweet pepper), green, red, yellow, orange, purple varieties
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake plants if needed. Harvest when fruits reach desired size and color - green peppers are immature, colored peppers are fully ripe. Warm-season crop. Watch for aphids and pepper maggots. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Tropical gourd in the Cucurbitaceae family with warty, bitter fruits, popular in Asian cuisine for medicinal and culinary use.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Provide trellis for vining habit. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest when fruits are 4-6 inches; younger fruits are less bitter. Warm-season crop - requires long, hot season. Popular in Asian cuisine. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Popular winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family with sweet, nutty flavor, excellent for storage.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space. Harvest when fully mature and rind is hard. Cure in warm place for 2 weeks before storage. Excellent for storage - can last 3-6 months. Sweet, nutty flavor. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Muskmelon, Rockmelon. Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Cucurbitaceae family, also known as muskmelon, requires long growing season.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week, increase during fruit development. Consistent moisture critical during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space. Harvest when stem separates easily from fruit and fruit has sweet aroma. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Watch for aphids and cucumber beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Golden berry. Fruit in the Solanaceae family with tart-sweet berries enclosed in paper husks, also known as golden berry or ground cherry.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Sprawling habit; may need support. Harvest when husks turn dry and papery and berries are golden. Can be eaten fresh or used in preserves. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Mirliton. Tender squash (mirliton) with edible fruit, shoots, and roots; vigorous vine.
careTips: Full sun. Provide strong trellis. Keep soil moist. Harvest when fruit is 4-6 inches. Young shoots and roots also edible. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Small, sweet tomatoes in the Solanaceae family, prolific and easy to grow, ideal for salads and snacking.
careTips: Deep, regular watering at base (2-3 times per week). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease. Consistent moisture prevents blossom end rot. Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Stake or cage indeterminate varieties. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with tomato fertilizer. Harvest when fully colored - prolific producer. Sweet and easy to grow. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Chinese varieties. Slender Asian eggplant in the Solanaceae family with tender, mild flesh and thin skin, ideal for stir-fries.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when skin is glossy and fruits are 6-8 inches long. Tender flesh, minimal seeds. Popular in Asian cuisine. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Maize. Tall grain crop in the Poaceae family, requires pollination from wind or manual assistance, plant in blocks for better pollination.
commonExamples: Zea mays (Corn, Maize), sweet corn, popcorn, and ornamental varieties
careTips: Regular deep watering (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist especially during tasseling and ear development - critical for kernel development. Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Plant in blocks (at least 4 rows) for better wind pollination. Fertilize when 12 inches tall and again when tassels appear. Tall plants - provide space. Ready in 60-100 days depending on variety. Watch for corn earworms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Large hybrid melon in the Cucurbitaceae family with sweet, aromatic salmon-pink flesh, casaba and Persian cross.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week, increase during fruit development. Consistent moisture critical during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space. Harvest when stem separates easily and fruit has sweet aroma. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Vining fruiting vegetables in the Cucurbitaceae family, need consistent moisture and support for climbing types.
commonExamples: Cucumis sativus (Cucumber), slicing and pickling varieties, bush and vining types
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering in hot weather). Water at base to avoid leaf diseases like powdery mildew. Consistent moisture prevents bitter fruit. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Provide trellis or support for vining types. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest regularly when fruits are young and tender. Ready in 50-70 days. Watch for cucumber beetles and powdery mildew. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Sweet potato squash. Cylindrical winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family with creamy, sweet flesh and edible skin, stores well.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when rind is hard and cream-colored with green stripes. Skin is edible when cooked. Cure before storage. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Young soybeans harvested green in the Fabaceae family, popular snack and vegetable, fast-growing.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Harvest when pods are plump and green but before they yellow. Fast-growing (75-90 days). Popular snack and vegetable. Boil or steam pods. Warm-season crop. Very popular in Asian cuisine. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Aubergine. Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Solanaceae family, also known as aubergine, requires long growing season.
commonExamples: Solanum melongena (Eggplant, Aubergine), 'Black Beauty', 'Japanese Long', 'Italian', 'Rosa Bianca'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake plants if needed. Harvest when skin is glossy and firm. Warm-season crop - start indoors in cool climates. Requires long growing season. Watch for flea beetles and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season vegetables grown for their edible fruits. Require long warm growing seasons and full sun for best production.
commonExamples: Solanum lycopersicum (Tomato), Capsicum (Pepper, Bell pepper), Cucumis sativus (Cucumber), Cucurbita (Squash, Zucchini), Solanum melongena (Eggplant)
careTips: Water deeply and consistently (1-2 inches per week). Water at base to avoid wetting foliage which can cause disease. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Rich, well-drained soil with plenty of organic matter. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer — switch to higher-phosphorus when fruiting begins. Stake or cage tall varieties (tomatoes, peppers). Mulch around base to retain moisture and prevent soil splash. Harvest regularly to encourage continued production. Most are frost-tender — plant after last frost date. Research specific vegetable for exact requirements.

description: Fast-growing legumes in the Fabaceae family, include bush and pole varieties, very popular vegetable.
commonExamples: Phaseolus vulgaris (Green bean, Snap bean, String bean), bush and pole varieties, 'Blue Lake', 'Kentucky Wonder', 'Provider'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Support pole varieties with trellis. Harvest when pods are young and tender (before seeds bulge). Fast-growing (50-60 days). Continuous harvest encourages more production. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Small fruit in the Solanaceae family with sweet, tropical-flavored berries in paper husks, related to tomatillo.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Sprawling habit. Harvest when husks turn dry and papery and berries drop - sweet when fully ripe. Use in pies, preserves, or fresh. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Very hot peppers in the Solanaceae family, among the hottest common peppers, use with extreme caution.
commonExamples: Capsicum chinense (Habanero), 'Orange Habanero', 'Red Habanero', 'Chocolate Habanero', 'Caribbean Red'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when fully colored (orange, red, or chocolate). Extremely hot - use gloves when handling. Warm-season crop - requires long, hot season. Very hot peppers - use with extreme caution. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Green-fleshed melon in the Cucurbitaceae family with sweet, smooth flesh and pale green to white rind.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week, increase during fruit development. Consistent moisture critical during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space. Harvest when rind turns creamy white or yellow and fruit has slight give. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Medium-hot peppers in the Solanaceae family, popular for salsas and cooking, can be mild to moderately hot.
commonExamples: Capsicum annuum (Jalapeño), 'Early Jalapeño', 'Jalapeño M', 'Mucho Nacho', 'Jalapeño Gigante'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when green for milder flavor, or when red for hotter flavor. Can be dried or smoked to make chipotle. Warm-season crop. Heat level varies by growing conditions. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Slender, elongated eggplant in the Solanaceae family with tender, creamy flesh and thin skin, minimal seeds.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when skin is glossy and fruits are 6-10 inches long. Tender flesh, ideal for grilling and stir-fries. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Round, yellow cucumber in the Cucurbitaceae family with mild, crisp flesh, heirloom variety.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily in hot weather). Water at base to avoid leaf diseases. Consistent moisture prevents bitter fruit. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when round and lemon-sized (2-3 inches) for best flavor. Mild, crisp, ideal for salads. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Gourd vine; young fruit edible as vegetable; mature fruit dries into natural sponge.
commonExamples: Luffa aegyptiaca (Egyptian luffa), L. acutangula (Angled luffa)
careTips: Full sun. Strong trellis. Water regularly. Harvest young for food (under 6 inches). Let mature and dry on vine for sponge. Long growing season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Loofah. Gourd vine in the Cucurbitaceae family; young fruit edible as vegetable; mature fruit dries into natural sponge.
careTips: Full sun essential. Strong trellis required for vining habit. Water regularly. Harvest young for food (under 6 inches). Let mature and dry on vine for sponge. Long growing season. Popular in Asian cuisine. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing legumes in the Fabaceae family, very popular in Chinese cuisine, can be sprouted.
commonExamples: Vigna radiata (Mung bean, Green gram), can be grown for beans or sprouts
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Fast-growing (60-90 days). Can be harvested as green pods or dried beans. Very popular in Chinese cuisine. Can be sprouted for bean sprouts. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Lady's finger, Gumbo. Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Malvaceae family with edible pods, also known as lady's finger, heat-loving.
commonExamples: Abelmoschus esculentus (Okra, Lady's finger, Gumbo), 'Clemson Spineless', 'Annie Oakley', 'Red Burgundy'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest pods when 2-4 inches long - daily harvesting encourages more production. Warm-season crop - very heat-loving. Tall plants may need staking. Watch for aphids and stink bugs. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Summer squash in the Cucurbitaceae family with scalloped, flying-saucer shape, mild flavor, harvest when small.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when 2-4 inches across for best flavor - tender and sweet. Bush habit, compact. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Garden pea. Cool-season legume vegetables in the Fabaceae family, prefer cooler temperatures and need support for climbing varieties.
commonExamples: Pisum sativum (Garden pea, English pea), shelling, snap, and snow pea varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base. Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in early spring or fall. Provide trellis or support for climbing varieties. Fertilize sparingly - peas fix their own nitrogen. Harvest regularly when pods are plump. Ready in 60-70 days. Watch for aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetables in the Solanaceae family, need consistent moisture and warm temperatures.
commonExamples: Capsicum annuum (Bell pepper, Chili pepper, Sweet pepper), various heat levels from sweet to very hot
careTips: Deep, regular watering at base (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Avoid water stress which causes blossom drop. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Warm temperatures required (70-85°F). Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake plants to support heavy fruit. Harvest when fruits reach desired size and color. Ready in 60-90 days. Watch for aphids and pepper maggots. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Large winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family, popular for Halloween decorations and cooking, require long growing season.
commonExamples: Cucurbita pepo (Pumpkin), C. maxima (Giant pumpkin), 'Jack O'Lantern', 'Sugar Pie', 'Cinderella', 'Atlantic Giant'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space (10+ feet). Harvest when fully mature and rind is hard. Cure in warm place for 2 weeks before storage. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Perfect for Halloween decorations. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Plum tomato. Plum tomato in the Solanaceae family with meaty, low-moisture flesh, ideal for sauces, paste, and canning.
careTips: Deep, regular watering at base (2-3 times per week). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease. Consistent moisture prevents blossom end rot. Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Stake determinate varieties. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with tomato fertilizer. Harvest when fully red and firm. Meaty flesh, few seeds. Ideal for sauces. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Edible-podded peas in the Fabaceae family, entire pod is eaten, prefer cool weather.
commonExamples: Pisum sativum var. macrocarpon (Snap pea, Sugar snap pea), 'Sugar Snap', 'Super Sugar Snap', 'Sugar Ann'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather - plant in early spring or fall. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Support with trellis. Harvest when pods are plump but before they become tough. Entire pod is eaten. Fast-growing (60-70 days). Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Mangetout. Flat-podded peas in the Fabaceae family, entire pod is eaten, popular in Asian cuisine.
commonExamples: Pisum sativum var. saccharatum (Snow pea, Chinese pea, Mangetout), 'Oregon Sugar Pod', 'Dwarf Gray Sugar'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather - plant in early spring or fall. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Support with trellis. Harvest when pods are flat and before seeds develop. Entire pod is eaten. Popular in Asian cuisine. Fast-growing (60-70 days). Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Essential legumes in the Fabaceae family, used for tofu, soy sauce, and many products, important crop.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Harvest when pods are plump and green (edamame) or when dry (mature beans). Essential crop. Used for tofu, soy sauce, and many products. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Oval winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family; cooked flesh separates into spaghetti-like strands, low-carb alternative.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when rind is hard and pale yellow. Bake or boil; flesh strands like spaghetti. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Large fruiting vegetables in the Cucurbitaceae family, vining types need support or space to spread.
commonExamples: Cucurbita pepo (Zucchini, Summer squash, Yellow squash), C. maxima (Winter squash, Pumpkin), C. moschata (Butternut squash)
careTips: Regular deep watering at base (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist especially during fruit development. Avoid wetting leaves to prevent powdery mildew. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Vining types need support or space to spread (10+ feet). Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest summer squash when small and tender; winter squash when fully mature. Watch for squash bugs and powdery mildew. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Green husk tomato in the Solanaceae family, essential for salsa verde, tart flavor when ripe.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Plant at least two for pollination. Harvest when husks split and fruits fill the husk. Essential for salsa verde. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetables in the Solanaceae family, require consistent moisture and support for vining types.
commonExamples: Solanum lycopersicum (Tomato), determinate and indeterminate varieties
careTips: Deep, regular watering at base (2-3 times per week, daily in hot weather). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease (early blight, late blight). Consistent moisture prevents blossom end rot (calcium deficiency). Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Stake or cage indeterminate varieties. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with tomato fertilizer. Mulch to retain moisture. Harvest when fully colored. Ready in 60-90 days. Watch for tomato hornworms and diseases. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Cucurbitaceae family, large vining plants require space and long growing season.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week, increase during fruit development. Consistent moisture critical during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Large vining plants require space. Harvest when tendril near stem turns brown and bottom sounds hollow when tapped. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Watch for aphids and cucumber beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Wax gourd. Large gourd in the Cucurbitaceae family with waxy coating, mild flavor, popular in Asian soups and stir-fries.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Provide strong trellis for heavy fruits. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks. Harvest when fully sized; waxy coating aids storage. Popular in Asian cuisine. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Yard-long bean. Long Asian bean in the Fabaceae family, can reach 3 feet, similar to green beans but more heat-tolerant.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Provide trellis for climbing habit. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Harvest when pods are pencil-thick, before seeds bulge. Heat-tolerant. Popular in Asian cuisine. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Summer squash, Courgette. Summer squash in the Cucurbitaceae family, fast-growing and prolific, harvest when small for best flavor.
commonExamples: Cucurbita pepo (Zucchini, Summer squash, Courgette), 'Black Beauty', 'Golden', 'Cocozelle', 'Ronde de Nice'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when 6-8 inches long for best flavor - daily harvesting encourages more production. Fast-growing and prolific. Male and female flowers. Watch for squash bugs and vine borers. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Garden beet, Red beet. Root vegetables in the Amaranthaceae family, both roots and greens are edible, prefer cool weather.
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris subsp. vulgaris (Beet, Garden beet, Red beet), 'Detroit Dark Red', 'Golden', 'Chioggia', 'Cylindra'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents woody roots. Water at base. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 3-4 inches apart. Harvest roots when 2-3 inches in diameter. Both roots and greens are edible. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Apiaceae family, require deep, loose soil free of rocks for straight roots.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents splitting. Water deeply to encourage long roots. Deep, loose, rock-free soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer - too much nitrogen causes forked roots. Thin seedlings to 2-3 inches apart. Harvest when roots reach desired size. Can be left in ground in mild climates. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Celery root in the Apiaceae family, grown for its edible swollen stem base with celery-like flavor, popular in European cuisine.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for bulb development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Hill soil around base as it grows. Harvest when bulb is 3-4 inches in diameter. Long growing season (100-120 days). Peel before cooking. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Mooli, Chinese radish. Large white radishes in the Brassicaceae family, popular in Asian cuisine, fast-growing.
commonExamples: Raphanus sativus var. longipinnatus (Daikon, White radish, Mooli, Chinese radish), 'April Cross', 'Minowase'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents pithy roots. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 4-6 inches apart. Harvest when roots are 6-12 inches long. Fast-growing (50-70 days). Popular in Asian cuisine. Can be stored for weeks. Prefer cool weather. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Finocchio. Bulb vegetables in the Apiaceae family with licorice flavor, both bulb and fronds are edible.
commonExamples: Foeniculum vulgare var. azoricum (Florence fennel, Finocchio), 'Zefa Fino', 'Orion'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for bulb development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when bulb is 3-4 inches in diameter. Both bulb and fronds are edible. Licorice flavor. Can bolt in heat - plant in spring or fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Perennial root in the Brassicaceae family with pungent, spicy roots used for condiments, can spread aggressively.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, deep soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize sparingly. Perennial - harvest roots in fall after frost. Can become invasive; consider containers or barriers. Grate roots when fresh for strongest flavor. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Sunchoke. Perennial sunflower relative in the Asteraceae family, grown for edible tubers (sunchokes), nutty flavor, can spread readily.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in spring. Perennial - harvest tubers after frost when plants die back. Can naturalize; contain with barriers if needed. Harvest as needed; stores in ground. Nutty, slightly sweet. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Shallot. Bulb vegetables in the Amaryllidaceae family, reduce watering as bulbs mature to prevent rot.
commonExamples: Allium cepa (Onion, Shallot), A. sativum (Garlic), A. fistulosum (Scallion, Green onion)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth (2-3 times per week). Reduce watering significantly as tops begin to yellow and bulbs mature - this allows bulbs to cure and prevents rot. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer until bulbs form. Plant garlic in fall for summer harvest; onions in spring. Harvest when tops fall over. Cure bulbs in dry, airy location. Toxic to pets. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Apiaceae family, flavor improves after frost, require long growing season.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents splitting. Deep, loose, rock-free soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 3-4 inches apart. Harvest after first frost for best flavor - can be left in ground over winter. Flavor improves after frost. Requires long growing season (100-120 days). Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Underground tuber vegetables in the Solanaceae family, require hilling (mounding soil) around stems as they grow.
commonExamples: Solanum tuberosum (Potato), early, mid-season, and late varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents hollow heart and ensures uniform tuber development. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Hill (mound soil) around stems as they grow to protect developing tubers from sunlight (which causes greening). Fertilize at planting and when hilling. Harvest when plants die back. Store in cool, dark place. Ready in 70-120 days depending on variety. Watch for potato beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing root vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, prefer cool weather and can be planted multiple times per season.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents pithy roots. Water at base. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 1-2 inches apart. Harvest when roots reach size (20-60 days depending on variety). Fast-growing. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Can be planted multiple times per season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Carrot. Vegetables grown for their edible underground parts, require loose well-drained soil for proper root development.
commonExamples: Daucus carota (Carrot), Beta vulgaris (Beet, Sugar beet), Raphanus (Radish), Pastinaca sativa (Parsnip)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents splitting and ensures uniform growth. Loose, well-drained soil essential - avoid heavy clay. Full sun preferred. Thin seedlings to proper spacing for root development. Fertilize sparingly - too much nitrogen causes leafy growth at expense of roots. Harvest when roots reach desired size. Ready in 30-120 days depending on variety. Research specific vegetable for exact requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Swede, Neep. Root vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, cross between turnip and cabbage, prefer cool weather.
commonExamples: Brassica napus subsp. rapifera (Rutabaga, Swede, Neep), 'American Purple Top', 'Laurentian'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents woody roots. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 6-8 inches apart. Harvest when roots are 3-5 inches in diameter. Prefer cool weather - plant in early spring or late summer. Flavor improves after frost. Can be stored for months. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Oyster plant. Root vegetable in the Asteraceae family with long white roots and oyster-like flavor.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Deep, loose, rock-free soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 4-6 inches apart. Long growing season (120 days). Harvest when roots are 8-12 inches long. Oyster-like flavor when cooked. Can be left in ground over winter. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season root vegetables in the Convolvulaceae family, also commonly called yams, require long growing season.
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during root development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Plant slips (rooted cuttings) after soil warms. Vining plants require space. Harvest before first frost when leaves start to yellow. Cure in warm, humid place for 2 weeks. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: Dasheen, Eddoe. Starchy root crop (corm) staple in Pacific and Asian cuisines; leaves and corms must be cooked before eating.
careTips: Wet or very moist soil. Partial sun. Warm temperatures. Harvest when leaves yellow. All parts contain calcium oxalate - must cook before eating. Toxic raw. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Also known as: White turnip. Root vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, both roots and greens are edible, prefer cool weather.
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. rapa (Turnip, White turnip), 'Purple Top White Globe', 'Tokyo Cross', 'Hakurei', 'Golden Ball'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents woody roots. Water at base. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 4-6 inches apart. Harvest roots when 2-3 inches in diameter. Both roots and greens are edible. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Flavor improves after frost. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family, require cross-pollination for most varieties, need winter chill.
commonExamples: Malus domestica (Apple), 'Gala', 'Fuji', 'Granny Smith', 'Honeycrisp', 'McIntosh', dwarf and standard sizes
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape and encourage fruiting. Most varieties need cross-pollination - plant 2+ compatible varieties nearby. Thin fruit for larger, healthier apples. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Harvest when easily twists off branch. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with velvety skin, early bloomers susceptible to frost.
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties are self-fertile. Early bloomers - very susceptible to late frosts. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Requires winter chill but blooms early. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Lauraceae family, require warm climates, popular for guacamole and salads.
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Well-drained soil essential - avoid waterlogged conditions. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and summer with avocado fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Most varieties need cross-pollination. Harvest when mature (varies by variety). Require warm climates - protect from frost. Can be grown in containers in cooler climates. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Tropical herb in the Musaceae family producing bunches of sweet fruits, each stem fruits once then is replaced by suckers.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Blackberry. Perennial cane fruits in the Rosaceae family, produce fruit on second-year canes, can be trailing or erect varieties.
commonExamples: Rubus fruticosus (Blackberry), trailing and erect varieties, thornless and thorny types
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit. Mulch around plants to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune fruited canes after harvest in summer. Support trailing varieties with trellis. Harvest when fully black and easily detaches. Can spread aggressively - contain with barriers. Replace plants every 8-10 years. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Acidic soil-loving berry shrubs in the Ericaceae family, require pH 4.5-5.5 and often need cross-pollination.
commonExamples: Vaccinium corymbosum (Highbush blueberry), V. angustifolium (Lowbush blueberry), V. ashei (Rabbiteye blueberry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Use acidic water if needed to maintain soil pH. Mulch with pine needles, pine bark, or sawdust to maintain acidity and moisture. Soil pH 4.5-5.5 essential - test and amend annually. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant 2+ compatible varieties. Prune in late winter. Harvest when fully blue. Research specific variety for exact requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Blackberry-raspberry hybrid in the Rosaceae family with large, tart-sweet berries, trailing cane habit.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family, sweet and sour varieties, require winter chill and often need cross-pollination.
commonExamples: Prunus avium (Sweet cherry), P. cerasus (Sour cherry, Tart cherry), 'Bing', 'Rainier', 'Montmorency', 'Stella'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties nearby. Protect from birds with netting. Harvest when fully colored. Sweet cherries are more challenging than sour cherries. Research specific variety for exact requirements. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Tropical palm in the Arecaceae family producing large drupes with edible meat and water, requires warm coastal climate.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Low-growing evergreen shrubs in the Ericaceae family, require acidic soil and constant moisture, popular for Thanksgiving.
commonExamples: Vaccinium macrocarpon (American cranberry), V. oxycoccos (Small cranberry)
careTips: Keep soil constantly moist - never allow to dry out. Acidic soil (pH 4.0-5.5) essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Mulch with pine needles or peat moss. Can be grown in boggy conditions. Harvest in fall when berries are fully red. Popular for Thanksgiving. Very challenging to grow outside native bog conditions. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Red. Deciduous shrubs in the Grossulariaceae family with red, black, or white berries, used for jams and fresh eating.
commonExamples: Ribes rubrum, R. nigrum (Red, black currant)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Date palm in the Arecaceae family producing sweet drupes, desert-adapted, requires hot dry climate.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: White-fleshed dragon fruit. Cactus fruits in the Cactaceae family, also known as pitaya, popular tropical fruit with striking appearance.
commonExamples: Hylocereus undatus (White-fleshed dragon fruit), H. costaricensis (Red-fleshed), Selenicereus (Yellow dragon fruit)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently (every 1-2 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Provide support for climbing habit. Self-fertile but cross-pollination improves yield. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Require warm climates. Popular tropical fruit. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous shrubs in the Adoxaceae family with clusters of dark berries, popular for health benefits and jellies.
commonExamples: Sambucus canadensis (American elderberry), S. nigra (European elderberry), 'Adams', 'York', 'Nova'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late winter to remove old canes. Most varieties need cross-pollination - plant 2+ varieties. Harvest clusters when fully ripe (dark purple/black). Berries must be cooked before eating. Toxic to pets - raw berries, leaves, stems contain cyanogenic glycosides. Popular for health benefits and jellies. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Moraceae family, can be grown in containers, some varieties produce two crops.
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late winter. Self-fertile. Some varieties produce two crops (breba and main crop). Can be grown in containers. Harvest when soft and drooping. Protect from cold in winter if needed. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Also known as: Wolfberry. Deciduous shrubs in the Solanaceae family, also known as wolfberry, popular superfood, drought-tolerant.
commonExamples: Lycium barbarum (Goji berry, Wolfberry), L. chinense (Chinese wolfberry)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 1-2 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late winter to maintain shape. Self-fertile. Harvest berries when fully red. Popular superfood. Can be grown in containers. Very popular in China. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous shrub in the Grossulariaceae family with tart green or red berries, popular for pies and preserves.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Wine grape. Perennial climbing vines in the Vitaceae family, produce clusters of berries, require pruning and support structures.
commonExamples: Vitis vinifera (Wine grape), V. labrusca (American grape), V. rotundifolia (Muscadine), table and wine varieties
careTips: Deep watering weekly during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune heavily in late winter - grapes fruit on new growth from previous year's wood. Provide strong support (trellis, arbor). Harvest when fully ripe and sweet. Many varieties need winter chill. Research specific variety for exact pruning requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Tropical tree in the Myrtaceae family with fragrant pink or white-fleshed fruits, fast-growing and adaptable.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Chinese date, Red date. Deciduous fruit trees in the Rhamnaceae family, also known as Chinese date or red date, drought-tolerant.
commonExamples: Ziziphus jujuba (Jujube, Chinese date, Red date), 'Li', 'Lang', 'Sugar Cane'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Self-fertile but better with cross-pollination. Harvest when fully red and slightly wrinkled. Can be eaten fresh or dried. Very popular in China. Drought tolerant. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Also known as: Kiwifruit. Vining fruit in the Actinidiaceae family with fuzzy brown fruit and green flesh, requires male and female plants.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Small citrus trees in the Rutaceae family, entire fruit is edible including peel, cold-hardier than most citrus.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun essential. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully orange. Entire fruit is edible including peel. Cold-hardier than most citrus - can tolerate light frosts. Can be grown in containers. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Blackberry-raspberry hybrid in the Rosaceae family with long dark red berries, trailing cane habit.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Dragon's eye. Evergreen fruit trees in the Sapindaceae family, related to lychee, require tropical or subtropical climate.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in spring and summer with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when skin is brown and fruit is sweet. Require tropical or subtropical climate. Related to lychee. Popular in Chinese cuisine. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Chinese plum. Evergreen fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with sweet, tangy fruits, popular in China and Japan.
commonExamples: Eriobotrya japonica (Loquat, Japanese plum, Chinese plum), 'Champagne', 'Gold Nugget'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring and summer with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain size and shape. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully yellow-orange and slightly soft. Can tolerate some cold but protect from hard freezes. Popular in China and Japan. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Lichi. Evergreen fruit trees in the Sapindaceae family with sweet, fragrant fruits, require tropical or subtropical climate.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, acidic soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in spring and summer with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile but cross-pollination improves yield. Harvest when skin is pink-red and fruit is fragrant. Require tropical or subtropical climate - protect from frost. Very popular in China. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Tropical tree in the Anacardiaceae family with sweet orange-fleshed drupes, widely cultivated fruit.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Deciduous tree in the Moraceae family with sweet black, red, or white berry-like fruits, fast-growing.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Sweet melon in the Cucurbitaceae family with aromatic netted rind, includes cantaloupe and similar varieties.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Smooth-skinned peaches in the Rosaceae family, genetic variant of peach, require winter chill.
commonExamples: Prunus persica var. nucipersica (Nectarine), 'Fantasia', 'Red Gold', 'Arctic Glo', 'Sunraycer'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties are self-fertile. Smooth skin unlike peaches. Thin fruit for larger nectarines. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Harvest when fully colored. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen tree in the Oleaceae family producing drupes for oil and table olives, Mediterranean origin.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Tropical herbaceous tree in the Caricaceae family with orange-fleshed fruits, fast-growing.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Tropical vine in the Passifloraceae family with tart-sweet purple or yellow fruits, exotic flavor.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Native North American tree in the Annonaceae family with custard-like tropical-flavored fruits.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with fuzzy skin and sweet flesh, require winter chill.
commonExamples: Prunus persica (Peach), freestone and clingstone varieties, 'Elberta', 'Redhaven', 'Georgia Belle'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties are self-fertile. Thin fruit for larger peaches. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Harvest when easily twists off branch. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with sweet, juicy flesh, most varieties need cross-pollination.
commonExamples: Pyrus communis (European pear), P. pyrifolia (Asian pear), 'Bartlett', 'Bosc', 'Anjou', 'Asian' varieties
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties. Harvest when mature but still firm - ripen off tree. Requires winter chill. Research specific type (European vs Asian) for exact requirements. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Ebenaceae family, astringent and non-astringent varieties, popular in both USA and China.
commonExamples: Diospyros kaki (Asian persimmon), D. virginiana (American persimmon), 'Fuyu', 'Hachiya'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Most varieties are self-fertile. Harvest astringent varieties when very soft; non-astringent when firm. Popular in both USA and China. Requires winter chill for best fruiting. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Tropical bromeliad in the Bromeliaceae family producing sweet aggregate fruits from the crown.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with smooth skin, many varieties need cross-pollination.
commonExamples: Prunus domestica (European plum), P. salicina (Japanese plum), 'Santa Rosa', 'Methley', 'Stanley'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties. Thin fruit for larger plums. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Lythraceae family with jewel-like seeds, drought-tolerant once established.
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully colored and makes metallic sound when tapped. Can be grown in containers. Requires hot summers for best fruiting. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Also known as: Pummelo, Shaddock. Large citrus fruits in the Rutaceae family, largest citrus fruit, popular in China and Southeast Asia.
careTips: Deep soak regularly during growing season. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun essential. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully yellow and fragrant. Largest citrus fruit. Require warm climates - protect from frost. Popular in China and Southeast Asia. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Cactus in the Cactaceae family with edible pads and sweet, colorful fruits (tunas), drought-tolerant.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Deciduous tree in the Rosaceae family with aromatic golden pomes, must be cooked - ideal for preserves.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Red raspberry. Perennial cane fruits in the Rosaceae family, produce fruit on second-year canes (floricane) or first-year canes (primocane) depending on variety.
commonExamples: Rubus idaeus (Red raspberry), R. occidentalis (Black raspberry), R. leucodermis (Blackcap raspberry), summer-bearing and everbearing varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune according to type - summer-bearing: remove fruited canes after harvest; everbearing: can be pruned for one or two crops. Support canes with trellis. Harvest when fully colored and easily detaches. Replace plants every 8-10 years. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Also known as: Garden strawberry. Low-growing perennial berry plants in the Rosaceae family, produce runners for propagation.
commonExamples: Fragaria × ananassa (Garden strawberry), June-bearing, everbearing, and day-neutral varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit which can cause rot. Mulch with straw or pine needles to keep berries clean and prevent soil contact. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and after harvest with balanced fertilizer. Remove runners first year to encourage fruiting; allow runners second year to propagate. Harvest when fully red. Replace plants every 3-4 years. Research variety type (June-bearing, everbearing, day-neutral) for exact requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cultivar of watermelon in the Cucurbitaceae family with sweet yellow or orange flesh instead of red.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Sweet basil. Annual culinary herb in the Lamiaceae family with aromatic leaves, essential in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines.
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum (Sweet basil, Genovese basil), O. basilicum 'Purple', O. tenuiflorum (Holy basil, Tulsi), Thai basil
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Pinch flowers immediately to prolong leaf production. Harvest regularly by pinching tips to encourage bushy growth. Very sensitive to cold - plant after last frost. Annual - replant each season.

description: Also known as: Bay leaf. Evergreen tree in the Lauraceae family with aromatic leaves used in soups, stews, and Mediterranean cooking. Can be grown as a container tree or shaped hedge.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest leaves as needed; dry before storing. Mulch to retain moisture. Mildly toxic to pets if ingested.

description: Also known as: Starflower. Annual herb in the Boraginaceae family with edible blue flowers and cucumber-flavored leaves. Used in salads, drinks, and as a companion plant for tomatoes and squash.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Green cardamom. Spice plant in the ginger family with aromatic seeds used in cooking and chai.
commonExamples: Elettaria cardamomum (Green cardamom, True cardamom), Amomum subulatum (Black cardamom)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist. High humidity. Partial shade. Warm temperatures. Harvest seed pods when green and before splitting. Tropical perennial.

description: Perennial herb in the Lamiaceae family with gray-green leaves. Known for attracting cats; leaves can be used in tea or as a calming herb for humans.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Herb in the Asteraceae family with daisy-like flowers used for soothing tea. German chamomile is annual; Roman chamomile is perennial. Both have apple-scented foliage.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Cool-season annual herb in the Apiaceae family with delicate anise- and parsley-like flavor. Essential in French fines herbes. Best in spring and fall; bolts in heat.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Nira. Perennial herbs in the Amaryllidaceae family with flat leaves and garlic flavor, essential in Chinese cuisine.
commonExamples: Allium tuberosum (Chinese chives, Garlic chives, Gow choy, Nira)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest by cutting leaves at base. Divide every 3-4 years. Perennial - returns each year. Garlic flavor. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Can be grown in containers. Edible white flowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial herbs in the Amaryllidaceae family with hollow, grass-like leaves, easy to grow.
commonExamples: Allium schoenoprasum (Chives), common chives, garlic chives (Allium tuberosum)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest by cutting leaves at base. Divide every 3-4 years. Perennial - returns each year. Easy to grow. Can be grown in containers. Edible purple flowers. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Coriander, Chinese parsley. Annual herb in the Apiaceae family, leaves (cilantro) and seeds (coriander) are both used, bolts quickly in heat.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bolting. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves regularly. Bolts quickly in heat - provide shade in summer or plant in fall. Annual - replant each season. Seeds (coriander) can be harvested when brown.

description: Perennial herb in the Boraginaceae family with large hairy leaves. Traditionally used externally for bruises and sprains. Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids—do not ingest; mild toxicity to pets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred. Fertilize regularly. Use as compost activator or mulch. Do not consume internally. Mildly toxic to pets when ingested.

description: Annual herbs in the Apiaceae family with feathery leaves and seeds, both leaves and seeds are used.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves regularly. Harvest seeds when brown. Can bolt in heat - plant in spring or fall. Both leaves and seeds are used. Attracts beneficial insects. Annual - replant each season.

description: Annual herb in the Amaranthaceae family with a pungent, medicinal flavor. Traditional in Mexican bean dishes to reduce gas. Used sparingly due to strong flavor.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Rhizomatous herbs in the Zingiberaceae family, essential spice in Chinese cuisine, can be grown from store-bought rhizomes.
commonExamples: Zingiber officinale (Ginger), common ginger, young ginger
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Partial shade preferred - avoid direct hot sun. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Plant rhizome pieces with eyes pointing up. Harvest when leaves die back (8-10 months). Can be grown in containers. Essential spice in Chinese cuisine. Rhizomes can be harvested partially. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.
