description: Also known as: Tulsi. Annual herb in the Lamiaceae family, sacred in Hinduism. Aromatic leaves with clove-like flavor used in Thai cuisine and Ayurvedic medicine. Different from sweet basil.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Culinary herbs grown indoors, require good drainage and regular harvesting to encourage bushy growth.
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum (Basil, Sweet basil), Mentha (Mint, Spearmint, Peppermint), Thymus (Thyme), Rosmarinus (Rosemary), Petroselinum (Parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained. Allow top inch to dry slightly between waterings. Avoid waterlogged soil - excellent drainage essential. Bright indirect to direct light (4-6 hours daily minimum). Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Harvest regularly to encourage bushy growth - pinch tips. Pinch flowers to prolong leaf production. Repot annually. Research specific herb for exact requirements.

description: Perennial herb in the Lamiaceae family with lemon-scented leaves. Used in tea, salads, and desserts. Spreads readily; can be invasive. Attracts bees.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Perennial grasses in the Poaceae family with lemony flavor, popular in Asian cuisine, can be grown in containers.
commonExamples: Cymbopogon citratus (Lemongrass, West Indian lemongrass), C. flexuosus (East Indian lemongrass)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize monthly with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer stalks at base. Divide every 2-3 years. Perennial in warm climates - treat as annual in cold. Can be grown in containers. Lemony flavor. Popular in Asian cuisine. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Tall perennial herb in the Apiaceae family with celery-like flavor. Leaves, stems, and seeds used in soups and stocks. Often grown as a substitute for celery.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Sweet marjoram. Tender perennial herb in the Lamiaceae family with a sweeter, milder flavor than oregano. Essential in Greek and Middle Eastern cooking. Often grown as annual in cold climates.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with aromatic leaves, can be invasive, spreads by runners.
commonExamples: Mentha spicata (Spearmint), M. × piperita (Peppermint), M. suaveolens (Apple mint), M. × villosa (Apple mint)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest regularly to control growth. Very invasive - grow in containers or use barriers to contain. Spreads by runners. Can be grown indoors or outdoors. Perennial but may die back in winter. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Wild marjoram. Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with pungent leaves, essential in Mediterranean cuisine.
commonExamples: Origanum vulgare (Oregano, Wild marjoram), O. vulgare subsp. hirtum (Greek oregano), O. majorana (Sweet marjoram)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest regularly by cutting stems. Pinch flowers to prolong leaf production. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Flavor intensifies when dried. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Curly parsley. Biennial herbs in the Apiaceae family, most commonly used as annual, curly and flat-leaf varieties.
commonExamples: Petroselinum crispum (Curly parsley), P. crispum var. neapolitanum (Flat-leaf parsley, Italian parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Biennial but usually grown as annual. Flat-leaf has stronger flavor. Can be grown indoors. Very common culinary herb. Mildly toxic to pets in large amounts. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Garden sage. Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with gray-green leaves, drought-tolerant once established.
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest leaves regularly. Prune to maintain shape. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Strong flavor - use sparingly in cooking. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Also known as: Summer savory. Herb in the Lamiaceae family with peppery, thyme-like flavor. Summer savory is annual; winter savory is perennial. Traditional in bean dishes and stuffings.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Annual herb in the Lamiaceae family with a mint-basil flavor. Green and red varieties used in Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese cuisine. Essential for sushi and banchan.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Also known as: Garden sorrel. Perennial herb in the Polygonaceae family with tangy, lemony leaves from oxalic acid. Used in soups, salads, and sauces. French sorrel has milder flavor.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Tender perennial herb in the Asteraceae family. Leaves are intensely sweet—used as natural sugar substitute. Native to Paraguay; needs warm, frost-free climate.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Perennial herb in the Asteraceae family with anise-like flavor. French tarragon is the culinary standard; propagated by division. Essential in béarnaise and fines herbes.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Evergreen shrub whose leaves produce black, green, oolong, and white tea.
commonExamples: Camellia sinensis (Tea plant, Tea shrub), C. sinensis var. assamica
careTips: Acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5). Partial shade in hot climates. Avoid hard frost. Harvest young leaves (two leaves and a bud). Prune to encourage bush growth.

description: Also known as: Garden thyme. Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with small aromatic leaves, drought-tolerant once established.
commonExamples: Thymus vulgaris (Common thyme, Garden thyme), T. citriodorus (Lemon thyme), T. serpyllum (Creeping thyme)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest regularly by cutting stems. Can be grown as groundcover or in containers. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Rhizomatous herbs in the Zingiberaceae family, related to ginger, popular spice and natural dye.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Partial shade preferred. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Plant rhizome pieces. Harvest when leaves die back (8-10 months). Can be grown in containers. Related to ginger. Popular spice and natural dye. Requires warm climate - protect from frost. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial herb in the Polygonaceae family with spicy, cilantro-like flavor. Essential in Vietnamese pho and salads. Not a true coriander; thrives in warm, moist conditions.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Full sun preferred for most. Fertilize regularly during growing season. Harvest as needed. Mulch to retain moisture.

description: Perennial legume in the Fabaceae family. Major forage crop for hay and grazing. Nitrogen-fixing; deep roots. Also grown for sprouting.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained, neutral to alkaline soil. Drought tolerant once established. Harvest hay at 10% bloom. Inoculate seed with rhizobia.

description: Pseudo-cereal in the Amaranthaceae family. Gluten-free grain; seeds high in protein. Drought tolerant. Ancient crop of the Americas.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season crop. Harvest when seed heads dry and seeds rattle. Thresh when fully dry.

description: Perennial grass in the Poaceae family. Warm-season forage and turf. Tolerates poor soil, drought, and low fertility. Common in southern US.
careTips: Full sun. Tolerates sandy, acidic soil. Mow or graze regularly. Establishes slowly from seed. Low maintenance once established.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Cereal grain for malt, feed, and food. Spring and winter types. Tolerates cooler climates than wheat.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when heads bend and kernels hard. Two-row and six-row varieties.

description: Pseudo-cereal in the Polygonaceae family. Gluten-free; fast-growing cover crop. White flowers attract pollinators. Short season (70–90 days).
careTips: Full sun. Any well-drained soil. Sow late spring to midsummer. Harvest when most seeds brown (lower seeds may shatter). Good green manure.

description: Also known as: Rapeseed. Oilseed crop in the Brassicaceae family. Low-erucic-acid rapeseed for edible oil and biodiesel. Yellow flowers. Spring and winter types.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when pods dry and seeds rattle. Swath or direct combine when ready.

description: Tropical perennial in the Euphorbiaceae family. Starchy tubers staple in tropics. Must be cooked—raw contains cyanogenic glycosides. Drought tolerant.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Tropical crop—frost kills. Harvest roots 8–24 months. Propagate by stem cuttings. Process before consumption.

description: Tropical perennial grown as annual for oil-rich seeds. Produces castor oil; seeds contain ricin—highly toxic. Grown for industrial oil, not consumption.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Water regularly. Toxic to pets and humans—seeds contain ricin. Keep away from children and animals. Harvest seeds when capsules dry.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Desi and kabuli types. Nutrient-dense pulse; drought tolerant. Cool-season crop.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained, neutral soil. Inoculate with rhizobia. Harvest when pods dry and rattle. Allow plants to dry before threshing.

description: Perennial legume in the Fabaceae family. Forage and cover crop. Nitrogen-fixing; pink flowers. Short-lived perennial (2–3 years).
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Inoculate seed. Harvest hay at early bloom. Good for rotation and soil building.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Grown for grain, silage, and ethanol. Distinguish from sweet corn; field corn harvested when kernels dry.
careTips: Full sun. Rich, well-drained soil. Plant after soil warms. Heavy feeder—nitrogen critical. Harvest when husks dry and kernels hard (dent stage).

description: Annual shrub in the Malvaceae family. Grown for fiber (lint) and seed oil. Warm-season; needs long frost-free period. Upland and Pima types.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season crop. Harvest when bolls open and lint fluffs. Defoliate before pick for cleaner harvest.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Drought and heat tolerant. Black-eyed pea, crowder types. Grown for dried peas and forage.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest dry beans when pods brown and rattle. Bush and vining types available.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Broad bean; cool-season crop. Large seeds for drying or fresh use. Some avoid raw—contains vicine.
careTips: Full sun. Cool-season—plant early spring or fall. Inoculate with rhizobia. Harvest green pods when plump or dry beans when pods brown.

description: Perennial cool-season grass in the Poaceae family. Major forage and turf grass. Tolerates drought, shade, and heavy grazing. Endophyte varieties improve persistence.
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Adapts to many soils. Mow or graze regularly. Endophyte-free for horses (fescue toxicosis risk).

description: Annual in the Linaceae family. Grown for fiber (linen) and seeds (linseed oil, omega-3). Blue flowers. Cool-season crop.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant early spring. Harvest when seed capsules brown (90–110 days). Fiber types pulled when flowering.

description: Perennial climbing vine in the Cannabaceae family. Cone-like flowers (strobiles) used in beer brewing. Dies back in winter; regrows from rhizomes.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Provide tall support (15–20 ft). Toxic to dogs—causes dangerous fever. Harvest cones when papery and aromatic (late summer).

description: Annual fiber crop in the Malvaceae family. Bast fiber for twine, burlap, geotextiles. Tossa and white jute. Tropical to subtropical.
careTips: Full sun. Rich, moist soil. Warm-season. Harvest stems at flowering for fiber. Ret (retting) in water to separate fiber.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Small lenticular seeds—red, green, brown. High protein pulse. Cool-season; drought tolerant.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when pods dry and seeds rattle. Low-growing; combine or hand harvest.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Proso (common) millet and others. Gluten-free grain; drought tolerant. Short season (60–90 days).
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when seed heads dry. Birds love it—harvest promptly when ripe.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Small green beans for sprouting, dals, and noodles. Warm-season; drought tolerant.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest dry beans when pods turn dark and rattle. Also grown for sprouts.

description: Oilseed and condiment crop in the Brassicaceae family. Brown, yellow, oriental mustard. Seeds for oil and spice. Cool-season.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season. Harvest when pods dry and seeds rattle. Can be used as cover crop or green manure.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Cereal for oatmeal, feed, and hay. Cool-season; tolerates wetter soils than wheat. Spring and winter types.
careTips: Full sun. Tolerates heavy, moist soil. Cool-season crop. Harvest when panicles golden and kernels in hard-dough stage. Good nurse crop.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Nuts develop underground (geocarpy). Valencia, Spanish, Virginia types. Warm-season; needs sandy soil.
careTips: Full sun. Light, sandy, well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when foliage yellows; dig before frost. Cure 2–3 weeks before storage.

description: Pseudo-cereal in the Amaranthaceae family. Gluten-free; complete protein. Tolerates salinity and drought. Rinse seeds to remove saponins.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Cool-season; frost tolerant. Harvest when seed heads dry and seeds rattle. Rinse before cooking.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Staple grain grown in flooded paddies (lowland) or upland. Short-grain, long-grain, and aromatic varieties.
careTips: Full sun. Lowland rice needs flooded fields or constant moisture. Upland rice tolerates drier conditions. Harvest when panicles golden and grains hard.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Cereal for bread, whiskey, and feed. Winter rye is cold-hardy cover crop. Tolerates poor soil.
careTips: Full sun. Tolerates poor, acidic soil. Winter rye planted fall. Harvest when heads golden. Excellent cover crop for biomass.

description: Annual oilseed in the Asteraceae family. High-heat cooking oil; once used for saffron-like dye. Drought tolerant. Spiny varieties deter birds.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Drought tolerant. Harvest when plants dry and seeds loosen. Oil and confection types available.

description: Annual in the Pedaliaceae family. Seeds for oil and tahini. Drought and heat tolerant. Capsules shatter when ripe—harvest carefully.
careTips: Full sun. Warm, well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when lower capsules brown—plants mature unevenly. Non-shattering varieties available.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Grain, syrup, forage, and biofuel. Drought tolerant. Grain, sweet, and broomcorn types.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest grain when heads hard and red; syrup when stalks sweet. Frost-sensitive.

description: Annual legume in the Fabaceae family. Major protein and oil crop. Edamame (green), tofu, oil, feed. Nitrogen-fixing.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when pods dry and beans rattle. Inoculate with rhizobia. Rotate with corn.

description: Biennial root crop in the Amaranthaceae family. Grown as annual for sugar extraction. Cool-season; stores sucrose in taproot.
careTips: Full sun. Deep, well-drained soil. Cool-season. Harvest when roots 3–4 in diameter. Process for sugar or use as livestock feed.

description: Perennial grass in the Poaceae family. Tropical crop for sugar and ethanol. Tall canes store sucrose. Ratoons (regrowth) for multiple harvests.
careTips: Full sun. Tropical—frost kills. Plant stem cuttings (setts). Harvest when canes mature (12–24 months). Needs abundant water and heat.

description: Annual in the Asteraceae family. Confection (snack) and oil types. Oil types have small black seeds; high in linoleic acid.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when back of heads yellow and seeds dry. Protect from birds with bags or netting.

description: Perennial vine in the Convolvulaceae family, grown as annual. Starchy tuber roots; not a potato. Orange, white, purple flesh. Warm-season.
careTips: Full sun. Light, sandy soil. Warm-season. Plant slips. Harvest before frost when roots reach size. Cure 1–2 weeks for storage.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. Tiny gluten-free grain; staple in Ethiopia. Drought tolerant. Seeds minuscule—harvest carefully.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Warm-season. Harvest when seed heads dry. Cut and cure in field; thresh carefully—seeds easily lost.

description: Perennial cool-season grass in the Poaceae family. Premium hay for horses. Cylindrical seed heads. Grows well in cool, moist climates.
careTips: Full sun. Moist, well-drained soil. Cool-season. Harvest hay at early heading. Often mixed with alfalfa or clover. Non-bloating.

description: Annual herb in the Solanaceae family. Leaves contain nicotine; grown for commercial tobacco. Ornamental Nicotiana species differ. Not for consumption.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Water regularly. Toxic to pets—nicotine in all plant parts. Keep away from animals and children.

description: Annual grass in the Poaceae family. World's major cereal crop. Bread wheat (T. aestivum) and durum. Spring and winter types by planting season.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Winter wheat planted fall; spring wheat in spring. Harvest when heads golden and kernels hard (combine or cut when dry).

description: Bean sprouts from adzuki beans. Crunchy, mild, nutty. Harvest in 4–6 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Classic delicate sprouts from alfalfa seeds. Mild flavor; harvest in 5–7 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Colorful microgreens from amaranth. Pink or green; mild. Harvest at first true leaves (7–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Peppery microgreens from arugula seeds. Fast-growing. Harvest at first true leaves (7–10 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Aromatic microgreens from basil. Intense flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Vibrant red-stemmed microgreens from beet. Earthy, sweet. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild mustard-like microgreens from broccoli raab. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: High-sulforaphane sprouts from broccoli seeds. Nutritious; harvest in 4–6 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Nutty sprouts from buckwheat groats. Hulled for eating. Harvest when 1–2 in (3–5 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild microgreens from cabbage. Red or green. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Fine, feathery microgreens from carrot. Slow to germinate. Harvest at first true leaves (14–21 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Concentrated celery flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (14–21 days). Slower grower.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Colorful stems; mild spinach-like flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Bean sprouts from chickpeas. Hearty, nutty. Harvest in 3–5 days. Soak 8–12 hrs first.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Strong cilantro flavor in microgreen form. Harvest at first true leaves (12–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild, delicate sprouts similar to alfalfa. Harvest in 5–7 days. Rinse 2–3× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Peppery, fast-growing sprouts. Harvest in 5–7 days. Can grow on paper towel.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Aromatic dill flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Anise-like flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (12–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Aromatic, slightly bitter sprouts. Curry-like. Harvest in 4–6 days. Rinse 2× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Nutritious microgreens; mild cabbage flavor. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild, sweet microgreens. Purple or green. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild, sweet allium flavor, gentler than onion sprouts. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Bean sprouts from lentils. Earthy. Harvest in 3–5 days. Soak 8 hrs first.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild, mustard-like Japanese green. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Classic Asian bean sprouts. Crunchy; harvest when 2–3 in (4–6 days). Rinse 2–3× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Spicy, pungent microgreens. Red or green. Harvest at first true leaves (6–10 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild onion-flavored sprouts with a gentle allium bite. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days). Pre-soak seeds before planting.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Sweet, earthy. Slow germinator. Harvest at first true leaves (18–21 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Sweet pea tendrils and leaves. Harvest when 2–4 in (8–12 days). Soak peas 12 hrs before sowing. Re-cut for multiple harvests.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Spicy, colorful. Fast-growing. Harvest at first true leaves (6–10 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Nutty, tender sprouts from sesame seeds. Harvest when 1–2 in (4–6 days). Rinse 2× daily. Hulled seeds preferred.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mint-basil flavored microgreens from shiso (perilla). Green or red. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Sweet snow pea shoots and tendrils. Harvest when 2–4 in (8–12 days). Soak peas 12 hrs. Similar to pea shoots.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Tangy, lemony. Harvest at first true leaves (12–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Large bean sprouts from soybeans. Crunchy; cook before eating. Harvest when 2–3 in (4–6 days). Rinse 2× daily.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild, nutritious. Harvest at first true leaves (10–14 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Young seedlings harvested within 1-3 weeks of germination. Sprouts are grown in water only; microgreens are grown on a thin layer of soil or growing medium. Nutrient-dense and easy to grow indoors year-round.
commonExamples: Broccoli sprouts, Alfalfa sprouts, Sunflower microgreens, Pea shoots, Radish microgreens, Wheatgrass
careTips: Mist or water lightly 1-2 times daily to keep seeds and growing medium moist. Never let dry out, but avoid standing water which causes mold. Bright indirect light preferred (a windowsill or grow light). Good air circulation essential to prevent mold and damping off. No fertilizer needed — seeds contain all necessary nutrients. Use clean, food-safe containers and fresh seeds. Harvest sprouts in 3-7 days, microgreens in 7-14 days. Rinse sprouts twice daily. Succession sow every few days for continuous harvest.

description: Nutty, crunchy sunflower sprouts. Use hulled seeds. Harvest when 1–2 in (7–10 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild brassica; spoon-shaped leaves. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Mild, slightly peppery. Harvest at first true leaves (8–12 days).
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Peppery, aquatic. Harvest in 5–7 days. Keep moist.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Juiced or chewed; nutrient-dense. Harvest when 6–8 in (7–10 days). Second cut possible.
careTips: Mist or rinse 1–2× daily to keep moist. Bright indirect light. Harvest at first true leaves (typically 7–14 days). No fertilizer needed.

description: Ornamental flowering bulbs in the Amaryllidaceae family, include edible onions and ornamental varieties.
commonExamples: Allium giganteum (Giant allium), A. aflatunense (Persian onion), A. schubertii (Schubert's allium), A. christophii (Star of Persia)
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering. Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall. Full sun preferred. Well-drained soil essential. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Ornamental varieties have large, spherical flower heads. Naturalize well. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Deterrent to many pests. Perfect for borders and cut flowers. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Also known as: Hippeastrum. Large flowering bulbs in the Amaryllidaceae family, popular for indoor winter forcing, can rebloom with proper care.
commonExamples: Hippeastrum (Amaryllis), various colors and cultivars, single and double varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during active growth and flowering. Reduce watering after flowering as foliage dies back. For forcing: plant in fall, keep in cool dark place until shoots appear, then move to bright light. For outdoor: plant in spring in warm climates. Bright indirect to direct light. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Can rebloom with proper dormancy care. Large, showy flowers. Perfect for holiday displays.

description: Also known as: Poppy anemone. Spring-blooming tuberous perennials. Anemone blanda (early) and A. coronaria (poppy). Plant in fall; dormant after flowering.
careTips: Keep moist during growth and bloom. Full sun to partial shade. Plant tubers in fall. Reduce watering when foliage dies back. Allow foliage to yellow before removing. Toxic to pets.

description: Plants that grow from underground storage organs (bulbs, corms, tubers, rhizomes). Many are spring-flowering and require a winter chilling period.
commonExamples: Tulipa (Tulip), Narcissus (Daffodil), Crocus, Hyacinthus (Hyacinth), Lilium (Lily), Allium
careTips: Water moderately during active growth — keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering as foliage yellows and dies back after flowering. Do not cut foliage until fully brown — leaves feed the bulb for next year. Plant at depth of 2-3 times bulb height. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize at planting and again when shoots emerge in spring with balanced bulb fertilizer. Lift and store tender bulbs before frost in cold climates. Many spring bulbs need a winter chill period to bloom. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Arum lily. Tuberous aroid with elegant spathe flowers in white, pink, or dark cultivars. Grown as houseplant or garden bulb; goes dormant after bloom.
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering. Reduce watering when foliage yellows; allow dormancy. Bright indirect light indoors; full sun to partial shade outdoors. Well-draining soil. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth and throat irritation.

description: Tender rhizomatous bulbs with bold foliage and tropical flowers. Summer bloomer; lift before frost or mulch in zone 8+.
careTips: Full sun. Rich, moist soil. Water regularly in summer. Fertilize monthly. Lift rhizomes after frost; store dry over winter. Replant in spring.

description: Early spring bulb with blue star flowers. Naturalizes well. Plant in fall. Dormant after bloom.
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth; reduce when foliage dies. Allow foliage to yellow naturally. Toxic to pets.

description: Early spring flowering bulbs in the Iridaceae family, among first flowers to bloom, naturalize well.
commonExamples: Crocus vernus (Spring crocus), C. chrysanthus (Golden crocus), C. sativus (Saffron crocus), C. tommasinianus (Tommasini's crocus)
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry naturally after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes). Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Among first flowers to bloom in spring. Naturalize well - will spread over time. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Perfect for naturalizing in lawns or under trees. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Fall-blooming crocus. Red stigmas yield saffron spice. Dormant summer; leaves appear spring, flowers fall.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Water when leaves present (spring) and during bloom (fall). Harvest stigmas when flowers open. Dry before storing. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset.

description: Tuberous perennials with heart-shaped leaves. Florist cyclamen blooms winter; goes dormant in summer. Cool temperatures essential.
careTips: Bright indirect light. Cool (60–68°F). Water when soil dry; avoid crown. Reduce watering when leaves yellow (summer dormancy). Resume when new growth appears. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Jonquil. Spring-blooming bulbous perennials in the Amaryllidaceae family, planted in fall, naturalize well and are deer-resistant.
commonExamples: Narcissus (Daffodil, Jonquil), N. pseudonarcissus (Wild daffodil), trumpet, large-cupped, small-cupped, double, and miniature varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) with pointed end up, 4-6 inches deep. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally - don't cut until yellow. Naturalize well and multiply over time. Deer and rodent resistant. Excellent for naturalizing in lawns and gardens. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Also known as: Garden dahlia. Tender tubers with showy summer flowers. Thousands of cultivars. Lift before frost; store dry over winter.
careTips: Full sun. Rich, well-drained soil. Water regularly; stake tall varieties. Deadhead for continuous bloom. Lift tubers after frost; store in cool, dry place. Toxic to pets.

description: Fragrant spring corms. Plant in fall (mild climates) or spring. Tubular flowers in many colors. Tender—lift in cold zones.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant corms 2 in deep. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage yellows. Lift and store in cold-winter areas. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Snake's head. Spring bulbs with nodding, checkered or crown-shaped flowers. Snake's head (F. meleagris) and crown imperial. Plant in fall.
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Moist, well-drained soil. Plant bulbs on side (hollow crown). Keep moist during growth. Dormant after flowering. Toxic to pets.

description: Ornamental onion with large purple globe flowers. Late spring bloom. Deer resistant. Dormant after flowering.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth. Allow foliage to die back—don't cut until yellow. Naturalizes well. Toxic to pets (Allium family).

description: Also known as: Garden gladiolus. Summer flowering bulbs in the Iridaceae family with tall spikes of colorful flowers, excellent for cut flowers.
commonExamples: Gladiolus × hortulanus (Garden gladiolus), various colors and sizes, dwarf and standard varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (summer). Plant corms in spring after last frost. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize when shoots emerge and during flowering. Stake tall varieties. Lift corms in fall in cold climates and store over winter. Allow foliage to die back before lifting. Excellent for cut flowers. Plant in succession for continuous blooms. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Fragrant spring flowering bulbs in the Asparagaceae family, can be forced indoors or grown outdoors.
commonExamples: Hyacinthus orientalis (Common hyacinth, Dutch hyacinth), various colors and cultivars
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering. Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes). Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Very fragrant flowers. Can be forced indoors with pre-chilling. Naturalize slowly. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Perfect for spring borders and containers. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Hybrid spring bulb with slender stems and elegant flowers in blue, purple, white, or yellow. Plant in fall for spring bloom; goes dormant after flowering.
careTips: Plant bulbs in fall, 4–5 inches deep. Full sun. Well-drained soil essential. Water during spring growth and bloom; allow foliage to yellow before cutting back. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Bulbs go dormant in summer—no watering needed. Suitable for beds, borders, and cut flowers. Toxic to pets.

description: Also known as: Lily. Bulbous perennial flowering plants in the Liliaceae family with showy trumpet-shaped or recurved flowers, many are fragrant.
commonExamples: Lilium (Lily, Easter lily, Oriental lily, Asiatic lily), L. longiflorum (Easter lily), L. orientalis (Oriental lily), L. asiaticum (Asiatic lily), L. candidum (Madonna lily)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (spring-summer). Allow to dry slightly after flowering. Well-drained soil essential - avoid waterlogged conditions. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Plant bulbs in fall or early spring. Mulch to keep roots cool. Remove spent flowers but leave foliage until yellow. Divide bulbs every 3-4 years. Many are fragrant. Research specific type for exact requirements. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Early summer lily with upright, unscented flowers. Cold hardy. Plant in fall or spring. Multiply by scales or division.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs 4–6 in deep. Keep moist during growth. Stake if needed. Toxic to cats.

description: Also known as: Compact calla. Compact Zantedeschia with smaller spathes. Colors include pink, yellow, orange. Toxic to pets.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth and throat irritation.

description: Fragrant white Oriental lily. Mid to late summer bloom. Classic wedding flower. Toxic to cats.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Highly toxic to cats; can cause kidney failure. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested.

description: Fragrant late-summer lilies. Large, often spotted flowers. Stargazer and Casablanca types. Toxic to cats.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Highly toxic to cats; can cause kidney failure. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested.

description: Orange Turk's-cap lily with black spots. Lilium lancifolium. Naturalizes; can spread. Toxic to cats.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Light requirements vary by species. Fertilize during growing season. Highly toxic to cats; can cause kidney failure. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested.

description: Early spring bulb with grape-like blue flowers. Naturalizes aggressively. Plant in fall. Dormant after bloom.
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth. Allow foliage to yellow. Can spread—contain if desired.

description: Shamrock-like bulbs with triangular leaves. Purple or green. Can go dormant in summer. Often grown as houseplant.
careTips: Bright indirect light. Water when soil dry. Reduce when leaves die back (dormancy). Resume when new growth appears. Toxic to pets in large amounts.

description: Spring tuber with layered, rose-like flowers. Soak tubers before planting. Plant in fall (mild) or spring. Dormant after bloom.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Soak tubers 4 hrs before planting. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage yellows. Lift in cold zones. Toxic to pets.

description: Early spring bulb with blue bell flowers. Siberian squill naturalizes well. Plant in fall. Dormant after bloom.
careTips: Full sun to partial shade. Well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage dies. Allow leaves to yellow naturally. Toxic to pets.

description: Earliest spring bulb—white flowers often through snow. Plant in fall. Dormant by late spring. Naturalizes well.
careTips: Partial shade ideal. Moist, well-drained soil. Plant bulbs in fall. Keep moist during growth. Reduce when foliage dies. Do not cut leaves until yellow.

description: Highly fragrant summer bulb. White tubular flowers. Tender—lift before frost. Used in perfumery.
careTips: Full sun. Well-drained soil. Plant when soil warm. Water regularly. Stake if needed. Lift tubers after frost; store dry. Replant in spring. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset.

description: Spring-blooming bulbous perennials in the Liliaceae family, planted in fall for spring flowers, many varieties available.
commonExamples: Tulipa (Tulip), T. gesneriana (Garden tulip), single early, double early, triumph, Darwin hybrid, parrot, and fringed varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) with pointed end up, 6-8 inches deep. Full sun preferred. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally to feed bulbs - don't cut until yellow. Many varieties are treated as annuals in warm climates. Research variety type for exact requirements and bloom time. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Plants that grow fully or partially submerged in water, include floating, submerged, and emergent types.
commonExamples: Nymphaea (Water lily), Nelumbo (Lotus, Sacred lotus), Eichhornia (Water hyacinth), Pistia (Water lettuce)
careTips: Fully submerged or floating in water - no soil watering needed. Maintain water quality - clean, oxygenated water essential. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets placed in soil or water. Remove dead leaves and flowers regularly. Control algae growth. Some species are invasive - check local regulations. Water depth varies by species. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Perfect for ponds and water gardens. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Also known as: Duck potato. Aquatic pond plant (Sagittaria)—not the houseplant Arrowhead plant (Syngonium). Arrow-shaped leaves; grows in shallow water or pond edges. Edible tubers (duck potato).
careTips: Shallow water (2–12 in) or saturated soil. Full sun. Plant in pond margin or container. Divide when crowded. No soil watering—plant in water.

description: Cyperus (umbrella plant) for water gardens. Stems topped with umbel leaf whorls. Thrives in saturated soil or shallow water.
careTips: Shallow water or saturated soil. Full sun to partial shade. Keep roots wet. Tropical—protect from frost. No soil watering—grown in water.

description: Plants adapted to constantly wet or waterlogged soil, ideal for water gardens and pond edges.
commonExamples: Cyperus papyrus (Papyrus, Egyptian paper reed), Canna (Canna lily), Iris pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris), Sagittaria (Arrowhead)
careTips: Keep soil constantly moist or waterlogged - never allow to dry out. Can grow in shallow water (up to 6 inches). Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Ideal for water gardens and pond edges. Some species spread aggressively - contain with barriers. Remove dead foliage. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Adapted to constantly wet conditions. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Emergent wetland plants in the Typhaceae family, grow in shallow water or wet soil, can be invasive.
commonExamples: Typha latifolia (Common cattail, Broadleaf cattail), T. angustifolia (Narrowleaf cattail), T. domingensis (Southern cattail)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (6-12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes - contain with barriers or grow in containers. Remove seed heads to prevent spread. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Perfect for pond edges and water gardens. Provides wildlife habitat. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Tiny floating plants. Rapid spread; provides shade and filtration. Can be invasive. Often used in aquariums and small ponds.
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun to partial shade. No planting—add to water surface. Control spread; remove excess. Provides habitat for tiny aquatic life.

description: Floating aquatic with heart-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. Nymphoides prefers still water. Can spread—contain in small ponds.
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun. No planting—add to pond surface. Can be invasive; remove excess. Roots in water or muck. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Aquatic plants grown indoors in water containers or hydroponic setups.
commonExamples: Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo), Pothos in water, Philodendron in water, Spider plant in water
careTips: Keep roots submerged in water at all times. Change water weekly to prevent stagnation and algae growth. Use filtered or distilled water to avoid mineral buildup. Bright indirect light preferred. Add liquid fertilizer monthly at quarter strength. Clean container monthly. Some plants can transition from soil to water. Perfect for hydroponic setups or decorative water containers. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Sacred aquatic plants in the Nelumbonaceae family with beautiful flowers and edible roots, important in Chinese culture.
commonExamples: Nelumbo nucifera (Lotus, Sacred lotus, Indian lotus), various colors and sizes
careTips: Grow in shallow to deep water (6-24 inches). Never allow to dry out. Full sun essential. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets. Plant tubers in spring. Beautiful flowers bloom above water. Edible roots (lotus root), seeds, and leaves. Can be invasive - contain with barriers. Important in Chinese culture and Buddhism. Requires water garden or pond. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Aquatic vegetables from lotus plants in the Nelumbonaceae family, popular in Chinese cuisine, grow in water.
commonExamples: Nelumbo nucifera (Lotus, Sacred lotus), roots are harvested for food
careTips: Grow in shallow water (6-12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun essential. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer. Harvest roots when mature (fall). Popular in Chinese cuisine. Can be invasive - contain with barriers. Beautiful flowers. Requires water garden or pond. Research specific growing requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Tall marginal aquatic. Egyptian papyrus grows in shallow water or wet soil. Dramatic upright stems with fluffy tops.
careTips: Shallow water or saturated soil. Full sun. Tropical—protect from frost. Can grow in submerged pots. Fertilize occasionally in growing season.

description: Emergent aquatic plants in the Pontederiaceae family with spikes of blue flowers, ideal for pond margins.
careTips: Grow in shallow water (up to 12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Spreads by rhizomes - may need containment. Remove spent flowers to prevent self-seeding. Perfect for pond margins and water gardens. Attracts pollinators. Provides wildlife habitat. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Floating aquatic with fragrant white flowers. Aponogeton blooms spring and fall. Submerged planting; leaves float.
careTips: Plant in 6–18 in water. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with pond tabs. Can go dormant in hot summer. Flowers float on surface.

description: Floating aquatic with purple flowers. Highly invasive—illegal in some areas. Provides shade and filtration. Check local regulations.
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun. No planting—add to surface. Remove excess to control spread. Illegal in many US states—check before growing.

description: Iris species adapted to wet conditions, grow in shallow water or boggy soil, ideal for water gardens.
commonExamples: Iris laevigata (Japanese water iris), I. pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris), I. versicolor (Blue flag iris)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (up to 6 inches) or constantly wet, boggy soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Divide every 3-4 years to maintain vigor. Remove dead foliage. Perfect for pond edges and water gardens. Some species can be invasive - check local regulations. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone. Toxic to pets—rhizomes especially; keep away from pets.

description: Floating rosettes resembling lettuce. Spreads rapidly. Invasive in warm climates. Provides shade. Check local regulations.
careTips: Floats on still water. Full sun. No planting—add to surface. Control spread; remove excess. Illegal in some areas. Tropical—frost kills. Toxic to pets—keep away from pets.

description: Classic floating aquatic. Leaves and flowers float on surface. Plant in pots at pond bottom. Hardy and tropical types.
careTips: Full sun. Plant in soil at 6–18 in depth. Use aquatic pots. Fertilize with pond tabs. Remove yellow leaves. Trim roots when repotting. Mildly toxic to pets—may cause GI upset if ingested.

description: Also known as: Pinguicula. Carnivorous plants in the Lentibulariaceae family with sticky leaves that trap insects, include temperate and tropical species.
commonExamples: Pinguicula (Butterwort), P. vulgaris (Common butterwort), P. moranensis (Mexican butterwort), temperate and tropical species
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60-70%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Sticky leaves trap small insects. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Plants that attract, trap, and digest insects and other small prey. Adapted to nutrient-poor boggy conditions with high humidity and acidic, low-nutrient soil.
commonExamples: Dionaea muscipula (Venus flytrap), Drosera (Sundew), Nepenthes (Tropical pitcher plant), Sarracenia (North American pitcher plant), Pinguicula (Butterwort)
careTips: Use only distilled, rainwater, or reverse-osmosis water — minerals in tap water damage or kill carnivorous plants. Keep soil consistently moist; many prefer the tray method (sitting in 1 inch of water). Use nutrient-free soil (pure peat or sphagnum with perlite — never potting mix). Bright light essential (4-6 hours direct sun or strong grow lights). High humidity (50-80%) preferred. Never fertilize through soil. Do not trigger traps for fun — wastes plant energy. Many temperate species require winter dormancy (cool, reduced light). Research specific genus for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Darlingtonia. Unique carnivorous plant in the Sarraceniaceae family native to California and Oregon, requires cool conditions.
commonExamples: Darlingtonia californica (Cobra lily, California pitcher plant, Darlingtonia)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Prefer cool conditions - avoid heat. Bright indirect to direct light. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy period in winter. Unique cobra-like appearance. Very challenging to grow outside native range.

description: Popular tropical sundew from South Africa, easy to grow and forgiving of beginners. No dormancy required. Produces tall flower stalks and abundant sticky dew.
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light (6-8 hrs ideal). High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. No dormancy needed. One of the easiest carnivorous plants to grow.

description: Tropical butterwort (Pinguicula) from Mexico with rosettes of sticky leaves that trap insects. Produces showy flowers. No dormancy required.
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray or water when soil surface dries. Bright indirect light. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. No dormancy needed. Leaves may change form between carnivorous (summer) and succulent (winter) phases.

description: Tropical pitcher plants (monkey cups) from Southeast Asia with hanging pitcher traps. Highlanders and lowlanders have different temperature needs.
commonExamples: Nepenthes spp. (Tropical pitcher plant, Monkey cups)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Water when top of medium feels dry; avoid waterlogging. Bright indirect to filtered light. High humidity (60-80%+) essential - often grown in terrariums. Use only sphagnum moss or specialized carnivorous plant mix. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. No dormancy. Research highlander vs lowlander requirements for your species.

description: Carnivorous plants with modified leaves forming pitcher-shaped traps, include temperate and tropical species.
commonExamples: Sarracenia (North American pitcher plant), Nepenthes (Tropical pitcher plant, Monkey cups), Darlingtonia (Cobra lily)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. High humidity (60-70%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Fill pitchers with water if they dry out. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: Trumpet pitcher. North American pitcher plants native to boggy regions. Upright or hooded pitchers trap insects. Require winter dormancy. Can be grown outdoors in zones 6-9.
commonExamples: Sarracenia spp. (North American pitcher plant, Trumpet pitcher)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to full sun (4-6 hrs). High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy in winter (cooler temps, reduced watering). Fill pitchers with water if they dry out.

description: Also known as: Drosera. Carnivorous plants in the Droseraceae family with sticky, dewy leaves that trap insects.
commonExamples: Drosera (Sundew), D. capensis (Cape sundew), D. rotundifolia (Round-leaved sundew), temperate and tropical species
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Dewy appearance indicates healthy plant. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Also known as: VFT. Most famous carnivorous plant in the Droseraceae family, native to North Carolina, requires dormancy and pure water.
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water (minerals kill them). Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Reduce watering in winter dormancy but keep slightly moist. Bright indirect to direct light (4-6 hours daily). High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy period in winter (cooler temperatures, reduced light). Don't trigger traps unnecessarily - each trap can only close a few times.

description: Epiphytic plants in the Bromeliaceae family that grow without soil, absorb water and nutrients through their leaves.
commonExamples: Tillandsia (Air plant), T. ionantha (Sky plant), T. xerographica (King of air plants), T. usneoides (Spanish moss)
careTips: Soak weekly for 20-30 minutes in room temperature water. Mist 2-3 times per week between soaks. Shake off excess water after soaking - water left in center causes rot. Ensure good air circulation - never keep in closed containers. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly by adding fertilizer to soak water at quarter strength. Grow without soil - mount on wood, rocks, or display in air. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Tank bromeliads with colorful central cups that hold water. Leaves form a rosette; flowers emerge from the center. Epiphytic in nature.
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water - change weekly to prevent stagnation. Water soil when nearly dry. Bright indirect light. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly by adding diluted fertilizer to tank. Use well-draining orchid or bromeliad mix. Good air circulation. Pup (offset) removal after flowering.

description: Air plants (Tillandsia) - bromeliads that grow without soil, absorbing water through leaves. Display mounted on wood, rocks, or in terrariums.
careTips: Soak weekly 20-30 min in room temp water; mist 2-3x/week between soaks. Shake off excess water after soaking - water in center causes rot. Bright indirect light. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly in soak water at quarter strength. No soil - mount on wood, bark, or display in air. Good air circulation essential.

description: Large orchid genus with cane-like stems and sprays of flowers. Many types: nobile (cool rest), phalaenopsis-type (warm), others. Epiphytic.
careTips: Water when medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light - some tolerate more sun. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use bark-based orchid mix. Rest period varies by type - nobile needs cool dry rest for blooms. Research specific hybrid for exact cycle.

description: General category for plants that grow on other plants - see specific categories (Orchids, Bromeliads, Air Plants) for detailed care.
careTips: Mist regularly (daily to weekly depending on species). Soak mounted plants weekly for 15-30 minutes. Ensure good drainage - never let sit in water. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with diluted fertilizer. Grow without soil - mount on wood, bark, or in specialized epiphyte mix. Good air circulation essential. Research specific plant type for exact requirements - see Orchids, Bromeliads, Air Plants for detailed care.

description: Also known as: Oakmoss. Symbiotic organism (fungus + algae/cyanobacteria) growing on bark, rocks, or soil. Rarely cultivated; use for identification or terrarium accent.
commonExamples: Various lichen species (Reindeer moss, British soldiers, Oakmoss)
careTips: Mist regularly to maintain moisture - lichens absorb from air. High humidity and good air circulation. Bright indirect to low light depending on species. Do not fertilize. Display on bark or rocks. Very slow growth. Difficult to cultivate outside natural habitat - most are wild-collected for display.

description: Non-vascular bryophytes that require constant moisture and high humidity, absorb water through leaves.
commonExamples: Sheet moss, Sphagnum moss (Peat moss), Fern moss, Cushion moss, Haircap moss
careTips: Mist daily or multiple times per day to maintain constant moisture. Never allow to dry out completely - even brief drying can kill moss. High humidity (80%+) essential - use terrarium or enclosed space. Bright indirect to low light preferred; direct sun dries moss quickly. Use distilled or rainwater - tap water minerals can harm moss. Acidic conditions preferred. Perfect for terrariums and moss gardens. Very challenging to maintain outside natural habitat.

description: Epiphytic orchids with spray-like flower stems, often yellow "dancing lady" blossoms. Includes many intergeneric hybrids (Oncostele, etc.).
careTips: Water when medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light - more light than Phalaenopsis. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use bark-based orchid mix. Good air circulation. Pseudobulbs store water - slight wrinkling is normal between waterings.

description: Large family of epiphytic and terrestrial plants in the Orchidaceae family, many are popular houseplants with specific care needs.
commonExamples: Phalaenopsis (Moth orchid), Cattleya, Dendrobium, Oncidium, Paphiopedilum (Lady's slipper), many genera and species
careTips: Water when potting medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light preferred - avoid direct sun. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use specialized orchid potting mix (bark, sphagnum moss). Repot every 2-3 years. Good air circulation essential. Many species are epiphytic. Research specific genus for exact requirements.

description: Epiphytic fern in the Polypodiaceae family that can survive extreme drought by curling up and appearing dead.
commonExamples: Pleopeltis polypodioides (Resurrection fern, formerly Polypodium polypodioides)
careTips: Mist regularly (2-3 times per week). Soak mounted plants weekly for 15-30 minutes. Can survive drought by curling up - will revive when watered. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with diluted fertilizer. Grow without soil - mount on wood or bark. Good air circulation essential. Epiphytic - grows on trees in nature. Very drought tolerant for a fern.

description: Also known as: Graybeard. Air plant (Tillandsia usneoides) that hangs in draping strands. No roots in soil - absorbs moisture through leaves. Grows on trees in Southeast US.
careTips: Mist or soak 2-3x per week. Can dunk in water 10-20 min weekly. Shake off excess - never leave waterlogged. Bright indirect light. High humidity (50%+) preferred. No soil - hang or drape on branches, driftwood. Good air circulation. Tolerates mild freeze. Do not use copper - it is toxic to Tillandsia.

description: Large, sculptural air plant with silvery curly leaves. Xeromorphic - needs less water than most Tillandsia. Drought tolerant.
careTips: Mist 2-3x per week; soak 1-2x per month for 30-60 min. Shake off excess - water in crown causes rot. Thick leaves mean less frequent watering than other air plants. Bright indirect light. High humidity preferred. No soil - display on wood or in air. Tolerates neglect better than most air plants.

description: Monopodial orchids with strap leaves and large, colorful flowers. Often grown bare-root in baskets or with minimal media. Need high light and humidity.
careTips: Water daily to every few days when grown bare-root; when potted, water when nearly dry. Mist roots frequently. Bright light - more than Phalaenopsis. High humidity (60%+) essential. Fertilize weekly at quarter strength. Use coarse bark or grow in slatted basket without media. Good air circulation. Can bloom multiple times per year.

description: Climbing orchid (Vanilla planifolia) that produces the vanilla bean. Grows as a vine; needs support. Tropical, high humidity and warmth.
careTips: Water when medium is nearly dry (2-3x per week when growing). High humidity (80%+) essential - greenhouse or terrarium ideal. Bright indirect to filtered light. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer. Use orchid bark mix. Provide sturdy support for vining growth. Flowers only with maturity (several years) and hand-pollination. Beans develop after pollination.

description: Compact alpine aster with daisy-like flowers in late spring to summer. Cold hardy, suited to rock gardens and alpine troughs.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens. Shear after flowering to contain. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Moss campion, Cushion pink. Moss-like alpine cushion plant with pink flowers. Silene acaulis forms dense mats ideal for rock gardens and crevices.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun preferred. Very drought tolerant. Fertilize sparingly. Slow-growing cushion form. Perfect for rock gardens, walls, and alpine troughs. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Plants adapted to high-altitude, rocky conditions with excellent drainage, many are drought tolerant.
commonExamples: Saxifraga (Saxifrage), Sempervivum (Hens and chicks), Dianthus (Pinks, Carnations), Gentiana (Gentian), Androsace (Rock jasmine)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty soil mix. Avoid waterlogged soil which causes root rot. Full sun preferred. Many are drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens. Adapted to high-altitude, rocky conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Delicate alpine poppies with crepe-paper flowers in white, yellow, or orange. Short-lived but self-seed. Cold hardy.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun preferred. Short-lived perennial - allow to self-seed. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens. Avoid excess moisture. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet. Toxic to pets—all parts; keep away from pets.

description: Mat-forming alpine perennial in the Brassicaceae family with masses of spring flowers, excellent for rock gardens.
commonExamples: Aubrieta deltoidea (Aubrieta, Rock cress), various cultivars and colors
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Shear after flowering to maintain shape. Mat-forming habit. Masses of spring flowers. Perfect for rock gardens, walls, and slopes. Very cold hardy. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Low-growing alpine bellflowers with blue or purple bells. Cold hardy, suited to rock gardens and crevices.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun to light shade. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens and walls. Very cold hardy. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet. Toxic to pets—keep away from pets.

description: Tiny alpine pink with single flowers, often pink or white. Compact cushion form. Cold hardy, ideal for rock gardens.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - alkaline soil preferred. Full sun. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly. Shear after flowering. Perfect for rock gardens. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet. Toxic to pets.

description: Small alpine crucifers forming cushions or mats with yellow or white flowers. Many species for rock gardens and troughs.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine troughs. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Iconic alpine plant in the Asteraceae family with woolly white flowers, symbol of the Alps, requires excellent drainage.
commonExamples: Leontopodium nivale (Edelweiss, Alpine edelweiss), L. alpinum
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty soil mix. Avoid waterlogged soil. Full sun preferred. Very drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine gardens. Challenging to grow outside alpine conditions. Symbol of the Alps. Requires cool summers. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Gentiana. Alpine and woodland plants in the Gentianaceae family with intense blue flowers, prefer cool, moist conditions.
commonExamples: Gentiana (Gentian), G. acaulis (Stemless gentian), G. septemfida (Crested gentian), G. sino-ornata (Chinese gentian)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained. Prefer cool, moist conditions. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine gardens. Many species are challenging to grow. Adapted to high-altitude conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Bitterroot. Alpine succulents with rosettes and showy flowers in pink, magenta, or white. Needs sharp drainage; crown must stay dry.
careTips: Water when soil is dry; avoid wetting crown - rot is common. Excellent drainage essential - grow in sloping rock or gritty mix. Full sun to light shade. Plant crown above soil level. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens. Challenging in wet climates. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Low alpine plants in the primrose family with white or pink flowers. Cushion- or mat-forming. Many species for rock gardens.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun preferred. Many species are challenging. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine troughs. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Rockfoil. Diverse alpine genus with cushion, mat, or rosette forms. Flowers in white, pink, or yellow. Many species for rock gardens.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty mix. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly. Perfect for rock gardens and walls. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Also known as: Houseleek. Succulent rosettes that multiply by offsets (chicks). Extremely cold hardy. Drought tolerant. Many colors and forms.
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun preferred. Very drought tolerant. Fertilize sparingly. Propagate by removing offsets. Perfect for rock gardens, green roofs, and containers. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.
